Company Profiles

As part of your market research assignment, you will give a short 5 to 10 minute presentation on your company. Your presentation should answer the following questions:

  • What incentives does the company offer to get people to participate?
  • How does it aggregate the information provided by the crowd?
  • What are the quality concerns, and how does the company do quality control?
  • How does the company benefit from user contributions?

Here are the companies that you are profiling this term:
MealKu is a co-op for exchanging homemade meals within your city.
Who were the founders? Ted D'Cruz-Young
When was it started? July 2012
Does it have any interesting origin story? Not really. I young hippie do-gooder kind of founder who wanted to come up with an organization to promote eating healthy, local food and reduce food waste. The founder also started a marketing agency called Ideocracy.
What services does MealKu provide? Mealku is basically a middleman that helps its members exchange food. Since there is no cost to receiving food, Mealku tracks points so that members have to put into the co-op (usually by providing food, but also by providing reviews and being active on the site) in order to receive food from the co-op. It also provides bicycle deliverymen and storage containers to transport the food from cook to consumer.
If this updates a previous service or business model, what does it replace? Fast food deliver/take-out.
Who uses the services? Health- and environment-conscious urban people. They say the goal is to make healthy food affordable, but it looks like you need a decent amount of cooking time and space in order to cook for other people, so I would imagine that most of the users are middle class.
Who are the people who contribute the services? The users and the contributors are the same crowd. You have to provide food in order to receive food.
How does MealKu incentivize them to contribute, or what is their motivation? People don't join unless they want to provide food. It is as much a community of hippie foodies as it is a way of getting free meals.
Is this a service that was previously provided by experts? Yes.
Are the contributors experts/professionals? No.
How does MealKu ensure the quality of the services it provides? Kitchen inspections, user reviews, and peer pressure.
If MealKu uses a reputation system, how does it work? Users can rate the meals they receive, both using a star system over several criteria (food quality, portion size, etc) and by leaving free form comments.
If its service is typically regulated by the government, what are the intents of the regulations and does the company meet those standards? The gov't doesn't currently regulate food exchanges that are not monetary. Mealku makes an effort to check that the cooks' kitchens are not cesspools of waste, but it mostly operates on the trust system.
Compare the number of users to contributors: Roughly equal numbers
If its service is provided by many contributors, how are their contributions aggregated? You only get points if others sign up to receive your food, and you can't receive food if you don't have points, so the crowd can end up filtering out the people who are making poor contributions.
Describe the workflow for how the service is advertised, how the contributors contribute, and what the users get in the end: Users sign up, pay a monthly fee to cover deliver and packaging. Then they post meals they intend to cook (about 3 days before they intend to do so). If people sign up to receive those meals (paying points to do so) then the cook prepares them as promised, a Mealku delivery biker comes to their house with to pick up the packaged food, and brings it to the person who ordered it. The person who ordered can review the cook online afterward. The cook receives points for having provided food.
What is the scale of MealKu in terms of users? ~1500
What is the scale of MealKu in terms of dollars? N/A
If MealKu were to scale up to 10-100 times its current size, how well do you think would its business model would work? Not very well. It depends on a local, trust-based community. It could probably scale well to many local organizations in many different cities, like a franchise model.
What kind of organization is it? Non-profit organization
How does MealKu generate revenue? They don't. It is a co-op, so they just need to stay afloat.
References
  • https://www.mealku.com/
  • http://www.jamieoliver.com/us/foundation/jamies-food-revolution/news-content/mealku-sharing-homemade-meals-online
  • http://cityroom.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/11/23/leftovers-made-to-share-with-strangers/?_php=true&_type=blogs&_php=true&_type=blogs&_r=1
  • http://online.wsj.com/news/articles/SB10001424052702304211804577500800856082254
  • http://www.today.com/food/do-you-mealku-potluck-craze-sweeps-home-kitchens-1C8613219
  • http://analisfirstamendment.blogspot.com/2012/08/interview-with-ted-dcruz-young-founder.html

Quirky crowdsources idea generation for new inventions, evaluation of that idea's feasibility and quality, and then manufactures and sells those inventions on their site.

Video profile: http://player.vimeo.com/video/106248014"
Who were the founders? Ben Kaufman
When was it started? 2009
Does it have any interesting origin story? Quirky arose when the founder's first business attempts at 18 years old failed miserably. He later decided that he could make invention and entrepreneurship more accessible by providing the platform for manufacturing, pricing, and sale - bringing the ideas of others to life.
What services does Quirky provide? For inventors, they pay for the genius of the crowd - they take your idea, let other people vote to determine the best, use a crowd of experts to select one each week for manufacture, then use non-experts to determine price points and decide design questions. Their employees manufacture it.

For consumers, they sell devices that improve life in some way - modular power strips solve the problem of large plug-ins blocking other ports, internet-connected piggy banks make saving money trackable and fun, and a plethora of cord and desk organizers, among many others.
If this updates a previous service or business model, what does it replace? It's a smaller-scale incubator, where the inventor isn't expected to have technical skills or marketing prowess. Quirky takes in an idea, uses people to evaluate its merit, then makes and sells it based on price points provided by the crowd.

What makes Quirky unique is that it pays people to be influencers rather than simply inventors - no other site incorporates the crowd so well.
Who uses the services? Anyone, from a suburban mom to a seasoned patent-holder, could pitch an idea for an invention - their bare minimum is a one-sentence description, not a technical write-up or elevator pitch. Anyone, anywhere, can influence the inventions by deciding details on it or voting for the highest-quality ideas.
Who are the people who contribute the services? There are no limitations or criteria preventing anyone from contributing, in an inventor or influencer role. In practice, inventors seem to be younger people who have encountered a problem repeatedly. There is no data released on influencers.
How does Quirky incentivize them to contribute, or what is their motivation? The company pays inventors - the people who pitch the original idea - 4.2% of the revenue of the product, assuming the product is manufactured and sold. It is easier to be an influencer; you can weigh in on design and price details of a product that is guaranteed to be rolled out, though of course your contribution is much less.
Is this a service that was previously provided by experts? Yes.
Are the contributors experts/professionals? No.
How does Quirky ensure the quality of the services it provides? Interestingly, at Quirky the crowd regulates itself via a voting system for ideas. However, there is involvement from experts (retailers, manufacturers, marketers) when, each Thursday night, the company meets and picks the next idea to manufacture. People weigh in on design concerns, and at the end of the night, the physical crowd (mixed between experts and non-experts) votes on whether or not they will manufacture something. If more than half of the crowd votes yes, the founder has committed to moving it to production.
If its service is typically regulated by the government, what are the intents of the regulations and does the company meet those standards? Typically, the government would protect the interests of investors by providing some type of intellectual property right. Quirky does not give credit to investors, but rather purchases the rights to an idea if they decide to use it, passing a share of the revenue along to the investor.
Compare the number of users to contributors: More users than contributors
If its service is provided by many contributors, how are their contributions aggregated? Contributions are aggregated via a simple majority. The most votes for non-quantitative options and the simple mean for quantitative options determine design specifications and prices, even product names.
Describe the workflow for how the service is advertised, how the contributors contribute, and what the users get in the end: The service does not seem to be advertised on any external sites, only on the shopping portal itself. If you decide to invent, you are brought to a form to describe your idea. Once that is completed, influencers can vote to indicate their favorite design ideas. Then the Quirky team decides whether or not they will produce it, at which point influencers can vote for design specifications, name, prices, etc.

Both inventors and influencers receive a fraction of the revenue if Quirky decides to produce it.
What is the scale of Quirky in terms of users? Quirky has nearly one million contributors, and has released 344 products since 2009.
What is the scale of Quirky in terms of dollars? Quirky has projected $100 million in earnings in 2014.
If Quirky were to scale up to 10-100 times its current size, how well do you think would its business model would work? It would likely work better the larger the crowd becomes. There would be more ideas proposed, and, assuming patient and thorough voters, the best would rise to the top, where a larger crowd would ensure better price points, names, and color choices. The quality would improve and Quirky would likely benefit from an even larger customer base.
What kind of organization is it? Privately held company
How does Quirky generate revenue? The company sells the devices after they are pitched, assessed, priced, and designed by the crowd. Quirky manufactures the devices, sometimes for sale on their website, sometimes in partnership with retail giants like Home Depot.
Anything else? I want to work for them! In a real, employee-type-way, not as an influencer. Being an inventor would be cool too.

References
  • https://www.quirky.com/how-it-works
  • many sub-sites of quirky.com
  • http://www.nytimes.com/2014/06/23/technology/quirky-hopes-wink-will-speed-adoption-of-smart-home-products.html?_r=0

Kaggle is a platform for data science competitions
Who were the founders? Anthony Goldbloom and Jeremy Howard
When was it started? April 2010
Does it have any interesting origin story? The founder, Anthony Goldbloom won an essay contest with The Economist and did a three month internship in the Finance and Economics Section. Here, he was writing about big data and in the process came up with the idea behind Kaggle. After the internship he taught himself to code at night and eventually created Kaggle 1.0.
What services does Kaggle provide? Kaggle offers a a framework for the competition, consulting service for the host to prepare the data and the description of the problem, anonymize the data, and integrate the winning model into their operations.
If this updates a previous service or business model, what does it replace? It replaces tech consulting firms since through this platform, even companies without internal data science teams can come up with predictive models for the problems they had.
Who uses the services? Researchers and organizations like NASA, Microsoft, Heritage Provider Network use this service. An example would be NASA's cosmological image analysis competition for mapping dark matter. Here, the participants were provided with images of 100,000 galaxy and star pairs, then based on the tiny distortions in the images, they were to provide an estimate for the ellipticity for each galaxy.
Who are the people who contribute the services? Students and data scientists from over 100 countries and 200 universities.
How does Kaggle incentivize them to contribute, or what is their motivation? Prize money and test data are some incentives. Some people use Kaggle to meet, learn, network and collaborate with experts from related fields.
Is this a service that was previously provided by experts? Yes.
Are the contributors experts/professionals? Yes.
How does Kaggle ensure the quality of the services it provides? n some senses, the service provided is self-regulated in terms of quality. Since the incentivize structure is set up as a competition, there would really be no point in entering the competition if you aren't going to make an honest attempt at the problem. It is technically possible that all the data scientists could collude, submit bogus solutions, and split the prize amongst themselves without doing any real work, but considering a large part of the incentive structure has to do with the challenge and glory of the competitions, this is not very likely.
If Kaggle uses a reputation system, how does it work? Kaggle users are allocated points for their performance in competitions. The overall user rankings are then shown on their website. Kaggle also separates its users into 3 tiers - novice, Kaggler, and master. Each tier is demarcated by a different color profile.
Compare the number of users to contributors: More contributors than users
If its service is provided by many contributors, how are their contributions aggregated? Kaggle presents problems in competition form, so many teams compete against one another to come up with the best solution to the problem. Although the teams are competing against one another, Kaggle is a way for some of the top minds to collaborate with others from all over the world, and the forum on Kaggle provides a great way for knowledge- and idea-sharing to take place.
Describe the workflow for how the service is advertised, how the contributors contribute, and what the users get in the end: When a company/institution has a predictive data problem they would like solved, they can create a simplified (or not) version of the problem and create a competition for it, offering a prize of their choosing for the winner. The competition is then posted on the competition board on Kaggle, where the contributors (Kagglers) can choose to tackle the problem by forming teams and signing up for the competition. Each team's ranking is tracked in real-time throughout the duration of the competition, and when the time for the competition is up, the winning team gets awarded whatever prize was offered, and each user is rewarded his/her respective points for completing the competition.
What is the scale of Kaggle in terms of users? 200,000 data scientists (contributors); at any time, there will be around 10-15 competitions (hosted by users)
What is the scale of Kaggle in terms of dollars? Up to $3 million in prize money
If Kaggle were to scale up to 10-100 times its current size, how well do you think would its business model would work? Our initial thought was that, because a decent proportion of the Kagglers are Ph.D.'s, there would be an upper limit to the number of Kagglers that could be drawn in join these competitions. However, upon further research, one article revealed that the typical competition winner on Kaggle is self-taught. With this in mind, and given the potential generous size of the prizes (up to $300 an hour) and the fun aspect of the competitions, we feel that Kaggle's ability to attract the necessary talent to solve these problems would scale up quite well without sacrificing quality of the data scientists. Similarly, given the rise of big data and the associated need for data analysis, we feel that the number of companies and institutions funding these projects, and hence the incentive scheme, would similarly scale up well (more projects, more available prize money). Another point to make is that a lot of the scientists are incentivized by the challenge and the glory Kaggle presents (as opposed to the money), all of which would remain (if not intensify) if Kaggle were to scale up.None that we are aware of
What kind of organization is it? Privately held company
How does Kaggle generate revenue? Kaggle charges a fixed fee to those hosting the competitions and also gets a proportion of prize money.
References
  • http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kaggle
  • http://www.wired.co.uk/news/archive/2012-04/03/kaggle
  • http://theminingbook.blogspot.com/2014/03/kaggle-matches-companies-and-analysts.html
  • http://www.fastcompany.com/most-innovative-companies/2014/industry/big-data
  • http://www.fastcolabs.com/3014018/the-rise-of-the-diy-data-scientist
  • http://www.wired.com/2011/12/kaggle/
  • http://www.crunchbase.com/organization/kaggle

Netflix is a media business, mainly focused on renting DVDs and unlimitedly streaming movies and TV shows.
Who were the founders? Marc Randolph and Reed Hastings
When was it started? 1997
Does it have any interesting origin story? Supposedly, Hastings came up with the idea for Netflix when he was charged $40 for late fees on a very late copy of Apollo 13.

(**ppt: Hastings got charged $40 for late fees - wasn't happy **)
What services does Netflix provide? Internet video streaming and disc rental.
If this updates a previous service or business model, what does it replace? They started with only an online disc rental service, which was pay per rental. After this, they added a subscription based service. From there, they drop the pay per rental and progressed to the internet streaming later on.
Who uses the services? People of all ages, including families and students will use this in lieu of going to their local rental movie place (which are all but nonexistent anymore). I've personally used this service to catch up on old TV series and watch movies that I either haven't seen before, or wanted to watch on a whim, opposed to planning a whole movie night and segmenting time to go and pick up a movie from BlockBuster or a RedBox.
Who are the people who contribute the services? The contributers of the service are the same people who purchase subscriptions to Netflix and watch the movies and TV shows
How does Netflix incentivize them to contribute, or what is their motivation? They are incentived not explicitly, but rather implicity by the results of the contributions. People's recommendations help rank what movies they enjoy, and help Netflix give suggestions for movies or shows they would probably like to see.
Is this a service that was previously provided by experts? No.
Are the contributors experts/professionals? No.
How does Netflix ensure the quality of the services it provides? Controversially, they have purchased highways of bandwidth, partnering with certain internet providers, so that their streaming service won't be interrupted or hampered.
Compare the number of users to contributors: More users than contributors
If its service is provided by many contributors, how are their contributions aggregated? They are aggragated according to an algorithm. This algorithm has changed a lot in recent years, and Netflix even offered a $1,000,000 prize to a person/team who could up with an algorithm that beats their current one by 10% for guessing what TV shows and movies people would watch.
Describe the workflow for how the service is advertised, how the contributors contribute, and what the users get in the end: The service is advertised heavily through internet ads, commercial TV ads, as well as word of mouth. Contributors contribute by rating a movie or show on a 5 star system through the site, prompted after they watch it. Users in the end get an aggregation from other users of the popularity of certain movies and how that might relate to their preferences.
What is the scale of Netflix in terms of users? On the order of 50 million users
What is the scale of Netflix in terms of dollars? The operating income is $228 million where the total assets are $5.4 billion.
If Netflix were to scale up to 10-100 times its current size, how well do you think would its business model would work? Netflix is primarily an English site, showing English movies, with the option of other languages subtitles as well as some small selection of foreign movies. Therefore, to scale up by 10 times, to ~500 million users, would hit the limit of English speakers of the world (currently ~430 million), so they would be limited by that factor. Their incentive scheme is already scaled to such a high number, that I don't believe it needs scaling, although the quality and aggregation model might need to adapt to more worldwide users, especially where people come from different cultures, even if speaking English, and consider how it may affect their contributions.
What kind of organization is it? Publicly traded company
How does Netflix generate revenue? They generate revenue through the subscriptions of their customers.

References
  • www.netflix.com
  • http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Netflix
  • https://www.linkedin.com/profile/view?id=17958160
  • http://techcrunch.com/2010/05/07/marc-randolph-bookrenter/

Stack Overflow is a crowdsourced question and answer site for professional and enthusiast programmers.

Video profile: http://player.vimeo.com/video/106395220"
Who were the founders? Jeff Atwood and Joel Spolsky
When was it started? 2008
Does it have any interesting origin story? Stack Overflow was created as a crowdsourced alternative to earlier Q&A sites like Experts Exchange. Interestingly enough, the name for the website was chosen by voting in April 2008 by readers of Coding Horror, founder Atwood's popular programming blog. As the primary purpose of the site was to help programmers solve and help each other with mainly technical programming issues, the terms 'stack' and 'overflow' can be put together to loosely mirror 'memory overflow' in meaning!
What services does Stack Overflow provide? The main purpose of stack overflow is to provide a forum for the online programming community to get together and discuss technical aspects across a wide range of programming languages and structures in an interactive and open Q&A format. The site has users who post both queries and answers and moderators who monitor postings and bulletins.
Who uses the services? Stack Overflow is used primarily by programmers working in nearly every kind of possible programming language or environment to troubleshoot problems, offer solutions to other problems in the community and to participate in finding answers in the field of computer science and programming. Each user first logs in with a free account and can then post queries that need answering and can provide working solutions and explanations to other ongoing query resolutions. Active members earn reputation points which make their answers more reputable.
Who are the people who contribute the services? The users are the contributors.
How does Stack Overflow incentivize them to contribute, or what is their motivation? By answering questions and getting solutions voted up by other community members on the site, contributors are encouraged to use Stack Overflow and improve their online reputation and coding profile. Special badges and achievements on the site profile can be unlocked, which leads to a very highly viewed profile that can be linked or referred to on other sites on the internet.
Is this a service that was previously provided by experts? No.
Are the contributors experts/professionals? No.
How does Stack Overflow ensure the quality of the services it provides? As the website is all about 'finding answers' the quality of the answers is collectively assessed by the 'crowd' of users actively participating in the community, through vote ups or vote downs and through reputation points. There are moderators who routinely run searches through threads to check for duplicated questions/old unanswered questions etc, but majority of quality control is user judged.
If Stack Overflow uses a reputation system, how does it work? Yes, users earn reputation points for their Stack Overflow account profiles (which show up on each question posted or answered). This raises the repute of high point-earners, making their answers much more reliable than beginners. There are also special badges and achievements which can be unlocked and added to the profile.
Compare the number of users to contributors: Roughly equal numbers
If its service is provided by many contributors, how are their contributions aggregated? Multiple users can provide answers to the same question/query. However, by the process of voting up the most relevant/accurate/efficient answer, the website crowdsources the process of ranking questions. All answers are shown by default, but higher voted up answers are shown first.
Describe the workflow for how the service is advertised, how the contributors contribute, and what the users get in the end: They don't delete repetitive posts, so there are a lot of keywords on the site, leading to it being at the top of search engine hits. Unanswered questions are listed under a tab on the homepage of the site, making it easy for people to answer questions. Contributors and users are the same people, and they answer and ask questions for the goal of sharing information.


What is the scale of Stack Overflow in terms of users? In 2012 they had over 175,000 users, the global site ranking is currently 49 and its 51 in the US.
What is the scale of Stack Overflow in terms of dollars? Their revenue is not listed publicly because it is a privately held company.
If Stack Overflow were to scale up to 10-100 times its current size, how well do you think would its business model would work? I think the incentive scheme would scale well, as long as Stack Overflow Careers could grow accordingly. With more users the quality would be even better, because there would be more feedback on the quality of the questions and answers. The only problem might be if there were not a balanced amount of questions and people answering questions.


What kind of organization is it? Privately held website
How does Stack Overflow generate revenue? Stack Overflow is a part of Stack Exchange which is an online package framework for a multitude of websites and they all generate revenue through ad listings on the website in strategic locations on the page - such as between questions and answers and next to question lists. In addition, Stack Overflow displays job positions and career options from external partner companies (mostly in the computer programming sector) which also add to the total revenue stream.

References
  • http://www.stackoverflow.com/tour
  • http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stack_Overflow
  • http://meta.stackexchange.com
  • http://www.stanford.edu/class/ee204/Publications/Finding%20a%20Growth%20Business%20Model%20at%20Stack%20Overflow.pdf

FiveThiryEight is a poll aggregator and data analysis website and blog.

Video profile: http://player.vimeo.com/video/106427753"
Who were the founders? Nate Silver
When was it started? March 7, 2008
Does it have any interesting origin story? The website was launched and quickly gained prominence during the 2008 presidential primaries and general election. 538 (at the time consisting of only founder Nate Silver) was unique in its approach to predicting the outcomes of primary elections, using a model based mainly on demographic information and past results in other states, rather than polls, to predict outcomes. In many cases, this model was more accurate than the traditional poll-based model, garnering significant attention for the site throughout the election cycle and beyond.
What services does FiveThirtyEight (538) provide? The site produces statistical analysis and blog content covering a wide range of subject matter. Most prominently, the site produces statistically modeled predictions for upcoming elections using polls published by other outlets and various other data. Other content categories include Sports, Economics, Science, and Life. In a typical post, a data-driven approach is taken to providing insight into a particular topic. For example, one of today's main features is America's Best Burrito, the last of a series of articles in which burrito shops from across the country (chosen based on Yelp data and expert opinions) have been scored using a prescribed methodology and a winner picked using a bracket-style competition. The feature focuses not only on burritos, but also on the reliability and usefulness of crowdsourced data found on sites like Yelp.
If this updates a previous service or business model, what does it replace? As a poll aggregator, 538 is similar to many services before it, including such companies as Real Clear Politics and the Princeton Election Consortium. Unlike these sites, 538 offers significant non-political content on top of its poll aggregation services.
Who uses the services? The service is meant for readers of all backgrounds who are seeking interesting and new insights into topics with which they are already familiar. The website is well designed, visually appealing, and easy to use. Much of the content is interactive, with infographics and charts which are click-able and customizable.
Who are the people who contribute the services? Contributors to 538 are its data sources and the site's staff of writers and data analysts. Data sources include various polls published by other (sometimes competing) publications. 538 has received criticism for its lack of transparency about the way in which its gathered polling data is used in its models.
How does FiveThirtyEight (538) incentivize them to contribute, or what is their motivation? FiveThirtyEight collects data by paying for it or gathering it from its publication on other sites. Thus, not all contributors to 538 necessarily do so willingly or knowingly.
Is this a service that was previously provided by experts? Yes.
Are the contributors experts/professionals? Yes.
How does FiveThirtyEight (538) ensure the quality of the services it provides? When polling, FiveThirtyEight uses large sampling pools and then applies several mathematical adjustments to these sampling pools to ensure the accuracy of its numbers.
Compare the number of users to contributors: More users than contributors
If its service is provided by many contributors, how are their contributions aggregated? FiveThirtyEight accumulates polling data from several polls and then calculates an adjusted score based on these parameters (http://fivethirtyeight.com/features/pollster-ratings-v40-methodology/).
Describe the workflow for how the service is advertised, how the contributors contribute, and what the users get in the end: FiveThirtyEight uses other polls and does not directly crowdsource.
What is the scale of FiveThirtyEight (538) in terms of users? The total number of users of 538's services is the number of readers which is not reported.
What is the scale of FiveThirtyEight (538) in terms of dollars? The total number of users of 538's services is the number of readers which is not reported.
If FiveThirtyEight (538) were to scale up to 10-100 times its current size, how well do you think would its business model would work? Scaling 538 to 10 or 100 times its size would not largely affect the business model. The company would require more employees to run statistical analyses, but because 538 compiles data rather than collects it, the business model would not be as other companies' who depend on data collection.
What kind of organization is it? Privately held company
How does FiveThirtyEight (538) generate revenue? FiveThirtyEight generates revenue by selling advertisements on its webpage. In the past, revenue was also generated by licensing content to be published elsewhere, notable by the New York Times from 2010 to 2013.
Anything else? 538 was not a perfect match for many of these questions because it uses data differently than many other consumer data-dependent companies. 538 does not directly generate revenue from its customers and thus cares less about their spending behavior. Obviously, 538 wants to increase its number of readers, but 538 has access to less consumer data because there are no transactions between 538 and its customers.
References
  • http://fivethirtyeight.com/
  • http://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2014/apr/22/upshot-vox-fivethirtyeight-data-journalism-golden-age
  • http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/FiveThirtyEight
  • http://fivethirtyeight.blogs.nytimes.com/

CrowdMed uses crowdsourcing to collaboratively solve even the world's most difficult medical cases quickly and accurately online.

Video profile: http://player.vimeo.com/video/106359616"
Who were the founders? Jared Heyman, Jessica Greenwalt, and Leonardo Setyano
When was it started? April 2013
Does it have any interesting origin story? From the website: After nearly three frustrating years, Carly was desperate for answers. She was clearly suffering from a serious medical condition, but nearly two dozen doctors, countless medical tests and over $100,000 in medical bills still could not tell her what was wrong. Carly had once been a vibrant, healthy teenager, but now she could barely get out of bed. Her symptoms and the emotional stress were pushing her and her family to the breaking point.

Finally, after a rare opportunity to consult with a top-notch interdisciplinary team of medical experts from the U.S. National Institutes of Health, Carly received an answer: Fragile X-associated primary ovarian insufficiency (FXPOI) - a rare genetic mutation found in just one of every 15,000 people. Even more astounding, the treatment of Carly's condition involved a simple hormone patch, which effectively eliminated all of her symptoms in less than one month.

Prior to her diagnosis, Carly was starting to wonder whether her life was already over. Today, Carly is fully recovered, with a new family of her own, and she is actively achieving all of her personal and professional goals.

Carly's medical mystery took nearly three years, two dozen doctors, and more than $100,00 in medical bills to diagnose.Her case was eventually solved after she had a rare opportunity to meet with a large, interdisciplinary team of top-notch medical experts - who all collaborated and worked together, and remained focused on the case for as long as it took to reach a consensus-based diagnosis.Thus, her brother, Jared Heyman, was inspired to start CrowdMed.
What services does CrowdMed provide? CrowdMed uses crowdsourcing and patented prediction market technology to diagnose rare conditions that doctors could easily miss, as well as offering “second opinions” to patients who may be unsure of the accuracy of their stated diagnosis. CrowdMed's patented technology uses the collective knowledge, intelligence, and unbiased opinions of thousands of “Medical Detectives” to present an accurate list of a patient's most probably diagnoses, sometimes in a matter of hours.
If this updates a previous service or business model, what does it replace? This service doesn't really replace the practice of health specialists and online health forums, but it does help in finding solutions faster and easier.
Who uses the services? Rip Heminway did a lot of running, soccer, back-country skiing, and white water kayaking. However, he started losing mobility and getting chronic pain. He said that a specialist would give him a list of different htings they think it might be, but never any kind of concrete clarity around what the problem was. He ended up spending thousands of dollars on specialists, blood tests, lab results, and the like. When he got his report from CrowdMed, he got a whole series of diagnoses which gave him a great foundation to work from. CrowdMed provided him to find succinct information. He is now pain-free and fully functional.
Who are the people who contribute the services? While most of the Medical Detectives are active in medicine, others might not be doctors but do have first-hand experience with specific medical conditions. CrowdMed has proven that many kinds of people can help solve medical mysteries - including researchers, students, and even former patients.


How does CrowdMed incentivize them to contribute, or what is their motivation? CrowdMed uses a point-based system to track Medical Detective performance and reward our community appropriately. By maximizing their point earnings, Medical Detectives can improve their ranking and reputation, earn the recognition of their peers, and even earn cash compensation offered by patients. Most importantly, Medical Detectives help patients get their lives back, which provides a sense of personal satisfaction in itself.
Is this a service that was previously provided by experts? Yes.
Are the contributors experts/professionals? Yes.
How does CrowdMed ensure the quality of the services it provides? CrowdMed uses a patented prediction market algorithm to assign probabilities to each diagnostic or solution suggestion based upon our Medical Detectives' background and behavior. They look for the most probable solutions, not just the most popular ones.

CrowdMed has devoted several years to develop patented prediction market methods to filter out any noise from all the input, to produce a report that highlights the top diagnostic and solution suggestions from the highest ranked Medical Detectives, which have the most confidence within the community.

Medical Detectives assign points to indicate their confidence in the suggestions offered to your case - a key component to the success and accuracy of the service. The points system requires people to prove their confidence, rather than just assume they're correct.


If CrowdMed uses a reputation system, how does it work? Cases are active for 30 days unless extended by the patient. At the end of this period, patients are asked to review the results with their physician and select the best diagnostic and solution suggestions. Medical Detectives who contributed to these suggestions are awarded points, status, and even cash compensation from those patients offering it - but the greatest reward for most of our Medical Detectives is knowing they've helped people get their lives back.

“Detective Rating System”. This system assigns a score to each Medical Detective on a 1-10 scale, which is expressed as their DetectiveRating (e.g., DR6). Inspired by Google's PageRank system, our DetectiveRating system provides a variable opinion weighting and special privileges to those Medical Detectives who perform the best on our site. For example, only DR6's and above can assign points on diagnostic and solution suggestions on cases offering cash compensation, thus influencing their probability rankings. Note, a peer rating from a DR8 carries twice as much weight as one from a DR4.


Compare the number of users to contributors: More users than contributors
If its service is provided by many contributors, how are their contributions aggregated? Cases are active for 30 days. When a case is posted, Medical Detectives provide well-researched and evidence-based diagnostic suggestions for patients to confirm with their doctors by posting them to the case. At the end of this process, contributions are aggregated, and the patient will receive a report which includes the top diagnostic suggestions and solution,along with supporting medical references and explanations from the community.
Describe the workflow for how the service is advertised, how the contributors contribute, and what the users get in the end: When a case is posted, Medical Detectives have the chance to provide input for the case. Medical Detectives may also use chat and discussion features to ask questions, request additional details, and discuss your case. At the end of this process, the patient will receive a report which includes the top diagnostic suggestions and solutions, along with supporting medical references and explanations from the community.
What is the scale of CrowdMed in terms of users? Information not available. Called the office and they said they could not disclose information not on the website.
What is the scale of CrowdMed in terms of dollars? In 2013 they received $1.1 million in seed funding.
If CrowdMed were to scale up to 10-100 times its current size, how well do you think would its business model would work? If the company were to scale up to 10 or 100 times its current size, I think that its business model would still work. The current quality/aggregation model would work even for bigger sizes; however, there may possibly be a need to better categorize cases if the number of cases significantly increases in order to help Medical Detectives better find the cases they would most likely be familiar with. The reputation model of the Medical Detectives may also change to put more emphasis on the professional credentials of the Detectives in addition to their contribution to the site.
What kind of organization is it? Non-profit organization
How does CrowdMed generate revenue? In terms of revenue, the company is currently charging a 10 percent commission on all cash rewards offered by patients for accurate diagnoses.
Anything else? I think that this company has a great idea; I'm surprised that there are no other companies just like it. CrowdMed does a great job providing information to those who may not have access to it; however, the quality of the obtained information must be carefully assessed.

References
  • https://www.crowdmed.com/our-inspiration
  • https://www.facebook.com/CrowdMed
  • http://blog.crowdmed.com/
  • http://www.crunchbase.com/organization/crowdmed
  • https://www.crowdmed.com/downloads/media-kit.pd

Shirt.woot, a sub-site of the company woot (with the tagline “One day, one deal”), holds a weekly contest for users to submit t-shirt designs, where other users vote on the designs they like best, and the winner goes on sale for a discounted price.

Video profile: http://player.vimeo.com/video/106303351"
Who were the founders? Matt Rutledge
When was it started? Woot was founded on July 12, 2004, but shirt.woot was started until July 2007
Does it have any interesting origin story? Woot began in 2004, but quickly branched into it's first sub-site wine.woot, which offers daily deals on wine that they will ship to your home. Then came shirt.woot, which utilized the user voting schema. After branching off into even more sub-sites (kids.woot, deals.woot, computers.woot, tools.woot, electronics.woot, etc.) woot was acquired in 2010 by Amazon for an estimated $110,000,000.
What services does Woot (shirt.woot specifically) provide? It is an Internet retailer. It provides a community of artists and consumers, and allows amateur artists to release works to be reviewed by the community.
Who uses the services? In my personal experience, I subscribe to the email listserv, which sends out the one deal per day. If I like the design, then I have a limited time to buy the shirt before it either goes up in price, or runs out of stock.

Another use one might have would be that of an amateur artist. As an artist, you can submit designs for free. Have them be reviewed and commented on by peers in the community. And if you win, you can garnish $1000 plus $2 per shirt sold after the first day.
Who are the people who contribute the services? Amateur artists submit designs for the weekly derby, and professional artists submit designs to shirt.woot's staff picks. T-shirt buyers and artists vote on designs to decide what eventually gets printed and sold on the site.
How does Woot (shirt.woot specifically) incentivize them to contribute, or what is their motivation? Artists are motivated by the love of art, $1,000 for a top 3 position along with $2 for every unit sold after the first day. Users are incentivized by voting for shirts that they would like to see win, printed, and delivered to their door for a cheap price.
Is this a service that was previously provided by experts? Yes.
Are the contributors experts/professionals? No.
How does Woot (shirt.woot specifically) ensure the quality of the services it provides? They have individuals vote on which t-shirts they want -- so the ones sold are the ones most demanded by the consumers.

There are also staff picks where shirt.woot employees select designs to be printed outside of the derby.
If Woot (shirt.woot specifically) uses a reputation system, how does it work? The winners, whose shirts are sold at a discount, are determined via votes.
Compare the number of users to contributors: More users than contributors
If its service is provided by many contributors, how are their contributions aggregated? The weekly derby allows artists to submit designs for a 1 week period during which other artists and users will vote on designs. At the end of the week three designs are called the winners, and receive $1,000 + $2 per shirt sold after the first day.
Describe the workflow for how the service is advertised, how the contributors contribute, and what the users get in the end: Attract artists to submit designs to the curated store or weekly derby through the financial incentives described above. Contributors can either submit their t-shirt designs or vote on the designs they like best. If a designer is in the top 3 in voting, he will get paid $1000 the first day and $2 for every shirt sold the day after. The voters will get to purchase the t-shirts that won as well.
What is the scale of Woot (shirt.woot specifically) in terms of users? This information is not readily available.
What is the scale of Woot (shirt.woot specifically) in terms of dollars? This information is not readily available, as it's parent company Woot was bought by Amazon in 2010 for 110 million. However, it's parent company, Woot, had a $164 million dollars in revenue in 2008.
If Woot (shirt.woot specifically) were to scale up to 10-100 times its current size, how well do you think would its business model would work? The incentive scheme would scale well because you could raise the amount paid to artists to attract better quality artists. The quality/aggregation model would also be ok because the shirts are picked by users and the staff -- so more users would automatically mean a more robust aggregation model. If the service were to scale to 100 times size in terms of orders, fast distribution of the t-shirts to users might be an issue without a large enough staff to handle orders, generate t-shirts, and monitor the supply chain.
What kind of organization is it? Publicly traded company
How does Woot (shirt.woot specifically) generate revenue? It garners profit from the t-shirts sold.
Anything else? On select days woot will forgoe the One day, one deal mantra for a woot-off where deals are set with a fixed volume, and when all units are gone, another deal is put up within minutes. The users are shown a progress bar, but no specifics on the amount of units left in stock.

  • http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Woot#Bibliography,
  • http://www.ecommercebytes.com/cab/abn/y10/m07/i01/s01,
  • http://www.crunchbase.com/organization/woot,
  • http://techcrunch.com/2010/06/30/woot-amazon/

Kiva is a not-for-profit microfinance platform that allows moneylenders around the world to empower entrepreneurs with just $25

Video profile: http://player.vimeo.com/video/106435795"
Who were the founders? Matt Flannery and Jessica Jackley
When was it started? October 2005
Does it have any interesting origin story? Kiva was started by the couple Jessica Jackley and Matt Flannery. A lecture by Muhammad Yunus, the father of microfinance, was a call to tap into the power of micro lending. They spearheaded Kiva with entrepreneurs in Kenya, who struggled to get past the lack-of-captial hump. The company's name means 'unity' in Swahili.
What services does Kiva provide? They provide a service to local entrepreneurs, field partners, and individual lenders. Their 'social service' is provide entrepreneurs with a platform to accumulate funding. Kiva field partners--who can be microfinance institutions, nonprofits, schools, and social businesses--upload information about entrepreneurs onto Kiva. The field partners handle the disbursement of the funds raised on Kiva to the entrepreneur, who will pay them back with interest in time. Individual lenders are provided a simple, nearly net-zero way to support social projects--the money they contribute to entrepreneurs is paid back as Kiva credit to give to a new loan.
If this updates a previous service or business model, what does it replace? Kiva is an revolutionary add-on to typical microfinancing efforts. Not only does it organize and validate the loans disbursed by microfinance institutions, Kiva enables other organizations to become established microfinancers. This includes schools, non profits, and social enterprises, who all interface with a wealth of worthy entrepreneurs.

It 'recycles' loan money by crowdsourcing. Small donations by lenders accumulate into loans that the field partners can disburse. The entrepreneur still gets their funding, the field partner collects the same interest on the loan as usual, but the lender gets paid back in credit and the money can be reused more efficiently.


Who uses the services? As a lender (an average person browsing the internet to do social good), you 1)Sign up as a kiva lender, 2)Browse borrower profiles and choose someone to lend to 3)Get paid back in Kiva credit and start again @
Who are the people who contribute the services? Based on a January 31, 2013, survey by Kiva (“Kiva Lender Demographics for Kiva Field Partners”), Kiva lenders are 2/3 female and 1/3 male. About 67% of lenders are 35 or older, while about 20% of lenders are 25 - 34 years old. Over 60% of Kiva lenders have a college degree. Approximately 60% of Kiva lenders live in the United States. The rankings by total amount lent per country are as follows: United States (49.96%), Western Europe (14.33%), Canada (6.64%), Australia (3.05%), Asia Pacific (1.71%), Middle East / North Africa (0.34%), Central America / Caribbean (0.22%), South America (0.13%), Central and South Asia (0.09%), and Sub-Saharan Africa (0.05%).
How does Kiva incentivize them to contribute, or what is their motivation? As stated in the above report, these are the most common motivations for people who lend on Kiva:

● A method of helping other people.

● A way to share their personal good fortune with others.

● A way to help an individual improve their social and economic standing.

● A window to the world, allowing a lender to become exposed to different people and cultures.

● A way to connect with, or give back to, a region where they have traveled or lived.

● A way for a lender to help an individual who shares common characteristics to themselves (age, gender, family size/structure, profession, etc.).

Additionally, Kiva often releases timed incentives such as, “Donate in the next two days and have your donation matched,” to further encourage lending activity.
Is this a service that was previously provided by experts? Yes.
Are the contributors experts/professionals? No.
How does Kiva ensure the quality of the services it provides? They review profiles of potential borrowers before posting them as eligible to receive a loan. This is a good filtration system to keep the projects listed social impact-guaranteed.
If Kiva uses a reputation system, how does it work? They allow individual lenders to join Lending Teams, which give towards different loans as a group. Kiva puts up a Leaderboard for Lending Teams, which displays top giver and how much they've giving total. Currently, I see Kiva Christians and Carnegie Mellon on the Leaderboard.
If its service is typically regulated by the government, what are the intents of the regulations and does the company meet those standards? Many countries regulate the microfinance industry to prevent fraud, protect consumers, and stabilize financial markets. Regulations change from country to country; for example, the Reserve Bank of India requires that loans made to non-government microfinance institutions have a minimum term of 3 years. Kiva has found ways to work within these regulations by holding on to repaid loans for 3 years before sending repayments back to lenders. Other countries, such as Ecuador, impose interest rate caps and/or extra taxes on internationally-funded microfinance organizations; these regulations directly impact Kiva's field partners, who must find ways to comply.
Compare the number of users to contributors: More contributors than users
If its service is provided by many contributors, how are their contributions aggregated? An international network of 274 (as of September 8, 2014) microfinance organizations screens borrowers, posts loan requests to Kiva, disburses loans to borrowers, and collects repayments from borrowers. When a lender makes a loan, Kiva delivers the funds to the local Field Partner, who then takes charge of loan administration.


Describe the workflow for how the service is advertised, how the contributors contribute, and what the users get in the end: Kiva advertises 4 simple steps for lenders: 1)choose a borrower 2)make a loan 3)get repaid 4)repeat! The contributors give in step
What is the scale of Kiva in terms of users? As of September 8, 2014, there are 1,219,715 active lenders on Kiva who have funded 1,409,460 borrowers.
What is the scale of Kiva in terms of dollars? As of September 8, 2014, there has been $607,594,600 made in loans.
If Kiva were to scale up to 10-100 times its current size, how well do you think would its business model would work? Yes, The incentive--your money is paid back to you to give again--will always be a component of the Kiva model, even at a huge scale. The quality of the user experience could go down, if it becomes impossibly hard to search for a great loan and some entrepreneurs never receive funds. (The amount of lender) * (the average amount of money they give) must always be nearly equal to the total amount of money that all loans on Kiva are asking for.
What kind of organization is it? Non-profit organization
How does Kiva generate revenue? Kiva is entirely dependent upon donations. For every loan they make, lenders are encouraged to donate an additional few dollars directly to Kiva: “The majority of Kiva donations are provided by our lenders, who 'tip' us on top of the loans they make to borrowers. … A large majority of the rest of our donation income is provided by foundations, who encourage us to create innovative programs to serve the poor more effectively (e.g. Google.org funding of Kiva Labs).”
Anything else? I think they're wonderful. I'm very curious who their first supporters were, because they have a web interface that's top of the line and obviously required some serious initial investments. There have been a few corrupt field partners, and the model they present isn't entirely honest (they distribute funds to the borrower before publicly posting their profile), but they get the job of microfinancing done with more efficiency and less uncertainty than has traditionally been seen.

References
  • www.Kiva.org
  • http://media.kiva.org/INNOV0201_flannery_kiva.pdf
  • http://www.cgdev.org/blog/kiva-not-quite-what-it-seems
  • http://blog.microfinancetransparency.com/whats-wrong-with-kivas-portfolio-yield-statistic/
  • http://limn.it/crowd-funding-and-its-challenges/

Thumbtack connects customers with local service providers.

Video profile: http://player.vimeo.com/video/106541260"
Who were the founders? Marco Zappacosta
When was it started? 2009
Does it have any interesting origin story? Not found online.
What services does Thumbtack provide? Thumbtack connects customers with local service providers through matching the customer demands for specific services with the people who can conduct such services locally. It also takes in account many details/factors of the demands and supply and provides optimal crowdsourced solution.
If this updates a previous service or business model, what does it replace?
Who uses the services? People who lives in a community and needs to outsource some work. Everyone can be a potential user.
Who are the people who contribute the services? It comes from a wide range of variety from DJ, cook, babysitters, etc.
How does Thumbtack incentivize them to contribute, or what is their motivation? Money.
Is this a service that was previously provided by experts? No.
Are the contributors experts/professionals? No.
How does Thumbtack ensure the quality of the services it provides? A reputation system on the service providers.
If Thumbtack uses a reputation system, how does it work? You can rate your experience with the service providers and leave direct comments on them.
Compare the number of users to contributors: Roughly equal numbers
If its service is provided by many contributors, how are their contributions aggregated?
Describe the workflow for how the service is advertised, how the contributors contribute, and what the users get in the end: Depending on the service you're asking for, you can get a list of local service providers. With further communication, you can set up detailed logistics with the service provider. You can enjoy the service in the end.
What is the scale of Thumbtack in terms of users? Not found online
What is the scale of Thumbtack in terms of dollars? Not found online
If Thumbtack were to scale up to 10-100 times its current size, how well do you think would its business model would work? For the quality of the service provider and potential frauds, the company needs to have a strong local maintenance team. In coordinating the logistics, the company also needs to improve its technology platform to be accustomed to higher demands.
What kind of organization is it? Publicly traded company
How does Thumbtack generate revenue? Charging part of the service fee you pay to the service provider.

Waze is a mobile GPS application that provides turn-by-turn directions and attempts to enhance the accuracy of travel times by using user-submitted road information to display for traffic delays and other real-time incidents.

Video profile: http://player.vimeo.com/video/106426603"
Who were the founders? Uri Levine, Ehud Shabtai, Amir Shinar
When was it started? 2008
Does it have any interesting origin story? Not particularly, but according to the About page on Waze's website, the idea for the company came from Ehud Shabtai because he was poor at navigating his way to places, and when given a GPS system, he had ideas about how to improve it.
What services does Waze provide? GPS and turn-by-turn directions
If this updates a previous service or business model, what does it replace? It enhances the accuracy of estimating travel times and traffic information, and other road information (such as speed traps, construction, etc.)
Who uses the services? The service can really be used by anyone who is trying to navigate from one place to another, and is not sure how to get there, or what the best route is. I have used Waze in the past and have found it to be great, with the traffic data being accurate and the interfacing being nice and very easy to use.
Who are the people who contribute the services? Anyone can contribute to the services, and usually the users themselves are the contributors
How does Waze incentivize them to contribute, or what is their motivation? Waze incentivizes contributors by having a social, game-like feature, where users earn points whenever they contribute road information, and as they accumulate points, their ranking in the Waze community increases. However, there does not seem to be a reward for accumulating points, besides validating your contributions to Waze.
Is this a service that was previously provided by experts? Yes.
Are the contributors experts/professionals? No.
How does Waze ensure the quality of the services it provides? Waze relies on the users to ensure the quality of the service – if road or traffic information is incorrect, Waze hopes that users will correct this within the app. For example, Wazers can add the presence of a speed trap on a road, but if a user finds that this speed trap is no longer there, Waze asks the user to update this information in the app.
If Waze uses a reputation system, how does it work? Waze's point system serves as the reputation system for the app. The more you contribute, the more points you get, and higher your rank within the Waze community. The point system is quite robust, and the method by which points are assigned can be found here https://wiki.waze.com/wiki/Your_Rank_and_Points#The_Table_of_Points


Compare the number of users to contributors: More users than contributors
If its service is provided by many contributors, how are their contributions aggregated? Waze has very complicated algorithms to aggregate the contributions, part of which depends on the points that the contributor has.
Describe the workflow for how the service is advertised, how the contributors contribute, and what the users get in the end: The contributors contribute by simply driving on the road with the Waze app open. If they run into traffic or notice anything noteworthy on the road (construction, police, an accident, etc.) they can update the map with this information in a hands-free method. This gives the users a real-time map of their surroundings, which ideally has the most accurate traffic and road information available.
What is the scale of Waze in terms of users? According to Yahoo, there were nearly 50 million Waze users as of June 2013.
What is the scale of Waze in terms of dollars? Waze was bought by Google for $1.1 billion but hardly generates revenues. They're revenue is not publicized, but it is known that it is less than $71 million.
If Waze were to scale up to 10-100 times its current size, how well do you think would its business model would work? I believe that for Waze, the more users the better. More users means more contributors, and more contributors means more accurate information on Waze in terms of traffic and road information.
What kind of organization is it? Privately held company
How does Waze generate revenue? Waze has a location based advertising system that they launched in October 2012, which provided a source of revenue. There are also sources that say that they sell traffic data to companies such as Apple, which is trying to improve its Maps application.
Anything else? N/A

References
  • http://www.forbes.com/sites/markrogowsky/2013/06/24/google-waze-delays-ahead/
  • http://authenticorganizations.com/harquail/2013/04/13/how-one-little-app-creates-a-boost-economy/#sthash.vRtCUEbl.dpbs
  • http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Waze
  • http://mashable.com/2013/06/12/what-is-waze/

Threadless sells t-shirts featuring the best designs submitted by artists and voted on by an active community.
Who were the founders? Jake Nickell and Jacob DeHart
When was it started? 2000
Does it have any interesting origin story? It was founded with only $1000 and was originally a simple community of artists.
What services does Threadless provide? Threadless provides both an online community and e-commerce platform.

The online community allows artists to submit t-shirt designs and for other artists and fans to rate those designs (and indicate whether they would purchase them).

The e-commerce platform then takes the highest rated t-shirts every week, pays the artists for the designs, and then sells t-shirts with those designs.


If this updates a previous service or business model, what does it replace? It is like a traditional online t-shirt retailer but crowsources the designs and maintains a highly active and invovled community.
Who uses the services? Digital artists and graphic designers, people interested in being part of a community, and people who want to buy creative t-shirts.

I once submitted a design a couple years ago but it fared poorly. I also voted for a t-shirt that succeeded and ended up buying it (I'll try and wear it to class one of these days).
Who are the people who contribute the services? Artists submit designs; 200,000 have done so to date,

Community members rate the designs and help the Threadless staff decide which ones to print; there are about 2.4 million of them.
How does Threadless incentivize them to contribute, or what is their motivation? Artists make money when their designs are printed.

Community members are rewarded by the feeling that they are empowered to choose which designs get printed. Threadless also hires community managers to organize real-life meet-ups and keep members engaged.
Is this a service that was previously provided by experts? Yes.
Are the contributors experts/professionals? No.
How does Threadless ensure the quality of the services it provides? The company's internal staff reviews the highest rated designs to make sure they are appropriate and of sufficient quality.
Compare the number of users to contributors: More users than contributors
If its service is provided by many contributors, how are their contributions aggregated? There votes are averaged to provide an aggregated score for each design.
Describe the workflow for how the service is advertised, how the contributors contribute, and what the users get in the end: Threadless advertises through banner ads all over the internet and SEM (I've seen a lot of advertisements personally in the last few years).

Contributors are either artists who then submit designs to the site. Communtiy members browse the designs and then rate and comment on them, indicating whether the shirt is something they would buy. Every week, the Threadless staff choose the 10 best designs and release them for sale, at which point anyone on the internet can purchase the t-shirts.


What is the scale of Threadless in terms of users? 2.4 million users
What is the scale of Threadless in terms of dollars? $30 million
If Threadless were to scale up to 10-100 times its current size, how well do you think would its business model would work? At 24 or 240 million users, the community would be significantly tougher to manage. Fake voting is already a problem but would become a much tougher problem to deal with after that scale. To ensure quality, raters could perhaps have karma points (based off of Reddit) or something similar that would assign a higher weight to their ratings given good behavior in the past.

Given that level of poularity, the company would have to also give its artists more money for each design to better motivate them,
What kind of organization is it? Privately held company
How does Threadless generate revenue? The company sells the community-chosen t-shirts.

References
  • http://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=6607681
  • https://www.threadless.com/

99designs crowdsources graphic design.
Who were the founders? Matt Mickiewicz, Mark Harbottle
When was it started? 2008
Does it have any interesting origin story? Matt Mickiewicz started SitePoint Solutions, a content and community website for designers and developers, at age 14. After the site's users started having informal design contests, Mickiewicz decided to create 99designs to separate a marketplace for crowdsourced graphic design.
What services does 99designs provide? Crowdsourced graphic design, primarily cheap logo and branding designs for small businesses, start-ups, and non-profits.
If this updates a previous service or business model, what does it replace? It replaces the informal design contests hosted on Mickiewicz's first company.
Who uses the services? Many small businesses, startups, and non-profit organizations use this service. An organization answers questions in an online brief, chooses a type of design package, and launches a contest. Designers then submit their designs, to which the company can give feedback. After a week, the company picks the winner, signs the copyright agreement, and the winning designer is paid.
Who are the people who contribute the services? The contributors are graphic designers who submit work to design competitions.
How does 99designs incentivize them to contribute, or what is their motivation? Winning the design competition means that the designer has won the competition holder's business (and is thus compensated for their work). 99designs plays on graphic designers' need for portfolio work, along with the prize of a significant amount of money, in order to motivate participants. Many of the graphic designers are entry-level designers.
Is this a service that was previously provided by experts? Yes.
Are the contributors experts/professionals? No.
How does 99designs ensure the quality of the services it provides? The company receives a large number of potential designers from its huge graphic designer contributor base. From the submitted designs, the company hosting the contest has the ability to provide feedback to ensure they're getting the design more geared towards their vision.
If 99designs uses a reputation system, how does it work? The more competitions a designer wins, the more opportunities they'll be selected for.
Compare the number of users to contributors: More contributors than users
If its service is provided by many contributors, how are their contributions aggregated? Designers find contests, to which they submit their design to. The contest host can sift through these designs.
Describe the workflow for how the service is advertised, how the contributors contribute, and what the users get in the end: 99designs markets easy design you'll love, allowing users to pick a type of design plan, the quality of the plan (bronze, silver, gold, platinum), with the assurance that the company will get a great design after a week. The plan quality relates to the number of designs a user receives and is allowed to provide feedback on. Graphic designers search for jobs best suited to their talents and post designs to the contest. Users get their chosen design at the end of the week, for the rate they initially agreed on.
What is the scale of 99designs in terms of users? 331,153 contests (not necessarily same as number of users)
What is the scale of 99designs in terms of dollars? $149 - $2,500
If 99designs were to scale up to 10-100 times its current size, how well do you think would its business model would work? I think its business model would still work well, assuming that the ratio of users to contributors remains the same / is higher. It could be possible the company would need to up its pricing packages, though I'm not sure. There are a huge number of businesses, start-ups, and non-profit organizations, and a great number of graphic designers trying to break into the business -- both who would be comfortable with using 99designs' services for the current pricing plans.
What kind of organization is it? Privately held company
How does 99designs generate revenue? Users are charged a fee for posting a contest on their site.
References
  • http://99designs.com/
  • http://www.entrepreneur.com/article/217577
  • http://99designs.knoji.com/similar-sites/
  • http://www.crunchbase.com/organization/99designs
  • https://www.linkedin.com/company/99designs

Postmates enables users to order from any restaurant or store by crowdsourcing people to make deliveries within an hour.

Video profile: http://player.vimeo.com/video/106361180"
Who were the founders? Sam Street, Sean Plaice, and Bastian Lehmann
When was it started? 2011
Does it have any interesting origin story? Not one that we can seem to find.
What services does Postmates provide? The company provides an on-demand delivery service with a guaranteed delivery time under one hour, in which the user's postmate can pick up a list of items from any restaurant or store for a delivery fee under $10 (depending on location). It's essentially like having a personal assistant for an hour who can go to any store and pick up items for you. As the Postmates website states: If it's an item in a store or restaurant in your city, we can deliver it. Get pizza from Little Star, donuts from Bob's Donuts, a new coat from Nordstrom, a picture frame from Crate & Barrel, you name it.
If this updates a previous service or business model, what does it replace? In a sense, Postmates updates Uber's delivery and pick-up service--Uber allows users to deliver an item to another location, or pick-up an item, but the Uber driver is not authorized to make a purchase on behalf of the user. Postmates are authorized to pay for your order, and you are charged upon delivery.

Additionally, Postmates is similar to Instacart. Instacart allows users to order groceries, and delivers them within one day (depending on the time of day in which the order was placed). On the other hand, Postmates has a shorter delivery time and has a larger selection of items.

Seamless and GrubHub allow users to order food from select restaurants, but Postmates allows users to order food from anywhere.

Moreover, whereas it may take a few days to order a clothing item online, users can order Postmates to go to an outlet that might sell that item and pick it up at the store so that the user can have it within an hour.
Who uses the services? Many people order food online through services such as Seamless or GrubHub, but it's frustrating when the restaurant from which you want to order is not on either website, or doesn't offer delivery at all. With Postmates, a user can order from any restaurant, and the Postmate will pick up the order and deliver it. Thus, Postmates attracts those who order in food, as well as people who may be busy and could use someone to run an errand or two for them, such as picking up their dry cleaning, or getting a last minute birthday present for a friend.

I've used this service many times before, either to pick up groceries or to order food from restaurants that don't deliver (Chipotle or Sweet Green for example), and it's been a pleasant experience every time. The app allows the user to track exactly where the Postmate is, which is great, since we've all had the experience of ordering food, and then calling the restaurant extremely frustrated at the fact that the food hasn't come in over an hour and the delivery guy has already left the restaurant. With Postmates, you know exactly where your delivery is, and if it is delivered in over an hour, Postmates will refund your purchase.
Who are the people who contribute the services? The couriers, or Postmates as they're referred to, come from all over. Some are parents or college students trying to make some extra money on the side, while others are people with delivery backgrounds such as GrubHub or Seamless delivery guys or FedEx drivers, Uber drivers, Lyft drivers, etc. According to the company website, To be a Postmate you must take pride in delivering exceptional customer service. There are a few other basic requirements - you must be over 18; own a bike, car, truck, scooter or motorcycle; and have an upbeat and positive attitude. Postmates must also complete a background check, attend a 30-minute orientation, and attend an onboarding session before being accepted.
How does Postmates incentivize them to contribute, or what is their motivation? The Postmates website states that experienced Postmates make up to $20/hour on weekdays and $25/hour on weekends, and contributors are allowed to choose their own hours, making for an attractive job to make a little extra cash.
Is this a service that was previously provided by experts? No.
Are the contributors experts/professionals? No.
How does Postmates ensure the quality of the services it provides? The company runs a thorough background check on each of its Postmates, as well as making each Postmate attend an orientation, run a few test jobs, and have an in-person interview. Moreover, the customer service for the app is fantastic, and if the Postmate takes over an hour to make the delivery, Postmates will refund the purchase.
If Postmates uses a reputation system, how does it work? After each delivery, you can rate the Postmate as well as write a review about that Postmate. When placing an order, you see your Postmate's name, photo, and rating.
If its service is typically regulated by the government, what are the intents of the regulations and does the company meet those standards? Only in the case of alcohol and cigarette deliveries. In these cases, the standards vary by state. For example, at the moment Postmates can deliver alcohol and cigarettes in New York, as long as the Postmate checks ID upon delivery, whereas in Philadelphia (where Postmates just recently launched within the past two months) Postmates cannot yet deliver alcohol or cigarettes.
Compare the number of users to contributors: More users than contributors
If its service is provided by many contributors, how are their contributions aggregated? N/A
Describe the workflow for how the service is advertised, how the contributors contribute, and what the users get in the end: At the moment, the majority of Postmates' expansion has been due to word-of-mouth rather than formal advertising campaigns. The contributors contribute by being available during their own set hours to make deliveries for the users, either by bike, car, or truck. This app allows users to pay a small fee to have practically any item that they could buy in a store delivered quickly to their home, making their lives easier and saving time.
What is the scale of Postmates in terms of users? As of April, 2014, Postmates were making an average of 10,000 deliveries per week.
What is the scale of Postmates in terms of dollars? Postmates hasn't disclosed their revenue.
If Postmates were to scale up to 10-100 times its current size, how well do you think would its business model would work? If the company were to scale to 100 times its current size, it would need to depend on a much larger workforce of postmates. For this reason, the customer review aggregation would become more important (all couriers we have encountered so far have had a 5 star rating). Additionally, Postmates currently has a culture in which the CEO himself meets with the Postmates, and social events are thrown each week. It may prove to be difficult to maintain this culture when the company scales, and so it may be beneficial for an academia system be set up in the various cities that is responsible for instilling the company's culture and requirement for good attitude. By maintaining this culture, and ensuring that all Postmates interact, the company may be able to scale while still ensuring a high service quality.

Furthermore, the company currently generates revenue by taking a percentage of the delivery fee, as well as payments made by restaurants to be featured on the home screen. If the company scales, then restaurants would be willing to pay a much larger fee to be featured on the home screen.
What kind of organization is it? Privately held company
How does Postmates generate revenue? The company hasn't disclosed its total revenue, but it generates revenue by taking a certain percentage of each delivery fee. It also has a smaller revenue stream coming from the preferred restaurants/stores that it features on the apps home screen.

References
  • https://postmates.com
