  • http://www.inc.com/magazine/201403/jill-krasny/same-day-delivery-startups.html
  • http://www.forbes.com/sites/meghancasserly/2013/05/30/kozmos-2-0-postmates-launches-new-york-flatiron/
  • http://pando.com/2014/04/08/see-you-in-the-trenches-ubers-threat-to-postmates-finally-hits-as-it-surges-to-10k-deliveries-a-week/
  • http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/09/16/bastian-lehmann_n_3935802.html
  • http://blogs.wsj.com/venturecapital/2014/02/18/postmates-picks-up-16m-for-local-delivery-of-anything-app/

Ushahidi creates crowd-sourcing applications for social activism, which are most useful for crisis response and political monitoring in the third world.

Video profile: http://player.vimeo.com/video/106429028"
Who were the founders? Ory Okolloh, Erik Hersman, David Kobia, Juliana Rotich
When was it started? 2008
Does it have any interesting origin story? Yes, it was founded during the aftermath of the 2007-2008 Kenyan election crisis. Meaning testimony in Swahili, Ushahidi was originally built so that the people of Kenya could report the political violence occurring through the country. It later expanded to serve a wide range of communities and problems through similar techniques.
What services does Ushahidi provide? The company aggregates information concerning political crises and natural disasters to inform the public and make reporting more accurate for the betterment of society.
Who uses the services? This is very difficult, as Ushahidi provides a variety of services and provides information to the public, rather than provide a service per se. A typical example of how somebody might use it would be when a crisis occurs. Especially during the beginning of the crisis, it is difficult for the government, local authorities, or other organizations to gather information and direct the public. Ushahidi allows the people to report information from the scene more easily, so that a person can simply look at the maps and better make decisions about how to react / where to go during the emergency.

Ushahidi's improved maps in Haiti were mentioned in class as an example. Additionally, they have done similar things after snow emergencies in Europe, flooding in the Missouri River Basin, and during the political unrest in Libya.
Who are the people who contribute the services? The people are the common citizens in an area in crisis. Quite typically, they are being affected by the crisis, and would like assistance. They likely represent a large part of the population, as anybody can report to Ushahidi as long as they own a cell phone (one can report events via text message, internet is not needed).
How does Ushahidi incentivize them to contribute, or what is their motivation? The contributors are often directly affected by the crisis, and would like to let others know what is happening. They are motivated by 1) the assistance they may receive by reporting their troubles and/or 2) the knowledge that they are helping their community/country.
Is this a service that was previously provided by experts? No.
Are the contributors experts/professionals? No.
How does Ushahidi ensure the quality of the services it provides? Ideally, the contributors are hoping to receive help, and would want to the advice they report to be accurate, and there is no direct incentive to give false information, especially in non-political crises.

Still, those who administrate the maps or other services do have the power to moderate content.
Compare the number of users to contributors: Roughly equal numbers
If its service is provided by many contributors, how are their contributions aggregated? Ushahidi aggregates contributions automatically without filtering by default, although those who organize a crowd-sourced map can moderate data. The ultimate goal of this crowd sourcing is to gather the information for human use, so their aggregation simply consists of collecting.
Describe the workflow for how the service is advertised, how the contributors contribute, and what the users get in the end: Presumably, the service spreads through word of mouth within the community and is encouraged by charitable/humane organizations. Users contribute via interactive maps (or via sms, email in the case of products other than Crowdmap). Their contribution can sometimes result in assistance being delivered to these people, and the available knowledge can often improve organized responses to the problem and shed light on the issue at hand.
What is the scale of Ushahidi in terms of users? The information gathered by Ushahidi can improve the lives of millions.
What is the scale of Ushahidi in terms of dollars? This is difficult to say as it is hard to give a price to information goods.
If Ushahidi were to scale up to 10-100 times its current size, how well do you think would its business model would work? If this scaling indicates the number of employee, the company could not grow by such a factor given it's relatively limited revenue. Already, much of the work and a sizable portion of the revenue come from voluntary contributors.

If this means the size of contributions, then it could scale quite easily, as the data is easily aggregated with little filtering.
What kind of organization is it? Non-profit organization
How does Ushahidi generate revenue? In addition to donations, the organization generates revenue by deploying its quality software for clients. Ushahidi emphasizes that it does not accept money from governments to maintain neutrality in political crises.
Anything else? This organization was a little difficult to profile as a non-profit. As such, revenue is not the main concern and we cannot analyze this company in the same way, especially when it comes to market analysis, incentives to users, competitors, etc. It was a very interesting company to profile because of this fact.

References
  • http://www2.technologyreview.com/tr50/ushahidi/
  • http://www.ushahidi.com/
  • https://wiki.ushahidi.com
  • http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ushahidi
  • http://www.no-straight-lines.com/blog/ushahidi-a-story-of-non-linear-innovation/
  • http://blog.standbytaskforce.com/2011/03/09/the-volunteers-behind-the-libya-crisis-map-a-true-story/
  • http://www.missionmode.com/blog/15-disaster-and-crisis-apps-for-iphone-and-ipad/

On October 19th, 2012, Iceland held the world's first ever “crowdsourced constitutional convention” online via Facebook and Twitter.

Video profile: http://player.vimeo.com/video/106347045"
Who were the founders? 2011 Iceland Constitutional Council (25 members)
When was it started? 2011
Does it have any interesting origin story? In 2008, a banking crisis resulted in the near-collapse of the Icelandic economy. The banks were heavily in debt due to the global recession and corruption among the political and banking elite. In addition, citizens were unhappy that many of the country's rich fishing and geothermal national resources were being increasingly owned by foreign interests. In 2009, the center-right government collapsed and was replaced by a government that appointed a council of 25 ordinary citizens to recommend constitutional reform to the Althing, the parliamentary body of Iceland.

94% of the population of Iceland (estimated at 324,000) have access to internet, making it one of the most “online” countries in the world. The constitutional council decided to solicit suggestions for constitutional reform on Facebook and Twitter via a six-question survey. After using the answers to this survey to develop an initial draft, the council gradually iterated over twelve drafts of the new legislation and consistently communicated with ordinary citizens via Facebook and Twitter. Updates of each draft were posted on a public website. Naturally, the opportunity to influence legislation made the survey incredibly popular. By the end of the voting period, over half of Iceland's voting-eligible body had contributed in some way to the process.


What services does Iceland's Crowdsourced Constitution provide? The Constitutional Council was an assembly of 25 people responsible for writing Iceland's new Constitution. At the beginning of their process of writing, they held a national vote on six yes/no questions for the citizens to vote on. During their process of writing, they made all of their drafts available to the public and posted videos of their meetings. They actively encouraged comments and feedback and incorporated that into their future drafts.

In short, they provided the service of giving citizens a voice in the writing of their Constitution.
If this updates a previous service or business model, what does it replace? It replaces the traditional way that Constitutions were written: by a small group of intellectuals in an intentionally secretive and obscured manner.
Who uses the services? The Constitutional Council posts a draft of the Constitution on Facebook and the public website, and a user can comment on it with feedback and suggestions.
Who are the people who contribute the services? Anyone with an internet connection could comment on the constitution Facebook or Twitter. Because the constitution is written in Icelandic, it is a foregone conclusion that only Icelandic nationals or expats would contribute.
How does Iceland's Crowdsourced Constitution incentivize them to contribute, or what is their motivation? Obviously, the ability for an ordinary citizen to potentially influence legislation, especially after an economic crisis, was a powerful incentive to participate.
Is this a service that was previously provided by experts? Yes.
Are the contributors experts/professionals? No.
How does Iceland's Crowdsourced Constitution ensure the quality of the services it provides? The Constitution wasn't /truly/ crowdsourced in the sense that the text that went into the Constitution did not for the most part come from “the crowd.” Instead, commenters' feedback was incorporated into the Constitutional Council's decisions as to what to include, exclude or change in their draft of the Constitution.
If its service is typically regulated by the government, what are the intents of the regulations and does the company meet those standards? Obviously, the ability to influence legislature is normally heavily “regulated”. A parliament member's ideas for change are regulated by his/her voting rights and the voting of all other members of the parliamentary body. In this case, the Althing, Iceland's parliamentary body, was dissolved before it could pass or reject the final draft because of political reasons. Elections were coming up and the ruling party was wary about experimenting with government legislature on a national scale.
Compare the number of users to contributors: More users than contributors
If its service is provided by many contributors, how are their contributions aggregated? For the initial poll of six yes/no questions, the results were simply aggregated by summing up the number of votes on each one. For the comments on the successive drafts of the constitution, members of the Constitutional Council would comb through all of the online comments and take them into consideration, and they would even regularly meet with the commenters.
Describe the workflow for how the service is advertised, how the contributors contribute, and what the users get in the end: The service was advertised via traditional social media channels (Facebook/Twitter), local and international publications, and the public website that continuously issued new drafts and newsletter updates. Initially, citizens answered a six-question yes/no survey that served as the base of constitutional reform (one of the questions was: “do you believe Iceland needs constitutional reform?”). Afterwards, the members of the council asked for direct written feedback on Facebook/Twitter, which they interacted with and incorporated into the drafts. In the end, citizens got an assurance that their suggestions were being taken into consideration.
What is the scale of Iceland's Crowdsourced Constitution in terms of users? 120,000 people
What is the scale of Iceland's Crowdsourced Constitution in terms of dollars? Iceland 2012 GDP: $13.66 Billion
If Iceland's Crowdsourced Constitution were to scale up to 10-100 times its current size, how well do you think would its business model would work? In general, I would guess that likelihood of success of a crowdsourced Constitution is inversely correlated with size of the country. For one, with more people, each person feels that his/her voice accounts for a smaller portion of the overall voice going into the Constitution. This leads to increased bystander effect and a lower participation rate (which was low in Iceland's case to begin with). This would lower the legitimacy of the Constitution's claim to truly represent all citizens' interests. Additionally, even though a lower percentage of people would participate, there would still be a higher volume of comments and feedback for the Constitution writers to comb through. This could lead to commenters trying to make more sensationalist comments for the sake of gaining Likes, Retweets, and Upvotes, just so they can get noticed, rather than truly substantive suggestions that writers can pick out for their own merits. Plus, most other countries do not have as high of prevalence of the Internet as Iceland does, so many citizens would be forcibly excluded due to their technical incapability. It is also unclear how this situation would play out in the United States, which has a much more diverse electorate and has a very polarized political system at present.
What kind of organization is it? Government body
How does Iceland's Crowdsourced Constitution generate revenue? Because we're discussing the use of crowdsourcing in a governmental context, this question seems non-applicable.
Anything else? This experiment unfortunately didn't get passed by the government, but its high engagement and large comment base suggest that this crowd-governance model may be something that we see popping up in isolated situations in bigger countries and perhaps affecting larger legislation in smaller countries with high Internet access like Iceland. Japan and/or South Korea would be good frontiers to try this next.

References
  • https://www.opendemocracy.net/can-europe-make-it/thorvaldur-gylfason/democracy-on-ice-post-mortem-of-icelandic-constitution
  • http://www.slate.com/articles/technology/future_tense/2014/07/five_lessons_from_iceland_s_failed_crowdsourced_constitution_experiment.html
  • http://www.governing.com/topics/politics/lawmaking/gov-iceland-writes-worlds-1st-crowd-sourced-constitution.html
  • http://www.democraticaudit.com/?p=2601
  • http://stjornarskrarfelagid.is/?page_id=2619
  • http://rendezvous.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/10/24/crowdsourcing-icelands-constitution/
  • http://www.verfassungsblog.de/en/putsch-icelands-crowd-sourced-constitution-killed-by-parliament-2/
  • http://qz.com/68910/icelands-experiment-with-crowd-sourcing-its-constitution-just-died/
  • For reference: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Icelandic_constitutional_reform,_2010%E2%80%9313
  • Article with video of them singing: http://singularityhub.com/2011/08/03/25-ordinary-citizens-write-icelands-new-constitution-with-help-from-social-media/

StackOverflow is the Google of coding help
Who were the founders? Jeff Atwood and Joel Spolsky
When was it started? 2008
Does it have any interesting origin story? Not really, the founders just saw an opportunity
What services does StackOverflow provide? The service allows users to post questions and view user-suggested and voted upon answers to the questions, in addition to allowing the users to search a database of prior Q&A's to help find a solution.
If this updates a previous service or business model, what does it replace? It basically is a search engine specialized to help with programming and writing code by searching a database of Q&A's for relevant answers or allowing users to post questions to be answered by the community.
Who uses the services? If I have a question about code I am writing, or I come across a tough bug, I search StackOverflow
Who are the people who contribute the services? Anyone can answer someone's question on stackoverflow, and can critique or upvote another user's answer to the question.
How does StackOverflow incentivize them to contribute, or what is their motivation? The company awards points and badges (social rewards) to users who provide good answers and has a leaderboard of the best responders
Is this a service that was previously provided by experts? Yes.
Are the contributors experts/professionals? Yes.
How does StackOverflow ensure the quality of the services it provides? The company will remove bad posts or mark them as non-questions, bad questions, etc and will do the same for answers. Additionally, the community will down-vote bad answers and up-vote good answers, so the user will know which answers to use for guidance.
If StackOverflow uses a reputation system, how does it work? Users register for an account, and can answer questions posed by Requesters. These questions are assigned a certain amount of Reputation by the Requester. The users then answer the question, and vote on others' answers. The Requester can then choose the answer that fixed his problem, and the reputation is assigned to whoever created that answer. Therefore, users with the consistently best answers will have the highest reputation.
Compare the number of users to contributors: More users than contributors
If its service is provided by many contributors, how are their contributions aggregated? Each question has its own webpage, that ranks all of the answers according to their votes and (if applicable) the answer chosen by the Requester
Describe the workflow for how the service is advertised, how the contributors contribute, and what the users get in the end:
What is the scale of StackOverflow in terms of users? Over 1.3 million registered users, many unregistered users visit the site a day
What is the scale of StackOverflow in terms of dollars? No fee to use, but would be at least millions in tech fees and lost productivity. It's also privately held, so there are no financials on the ads or job listings. It's enough to fund a website with a huge dataset and hundreds of thousands of daily page views.
If StackOverflow were to scale up to 10-100 times its current size, how well do you think would its business model would work? The business model would only be better. More users mean better and faster answers, with more users to filter out the bad answers and upvote the good answers.
What kind of organization is it? Privately held company
How does StackOverflow generate revenue? The company generates revenue through ads as well as job listings on their site
Anything else? A great website, and is part of a larger shell called Stack Exchange
References
  • stackoverflow.com
  • wikipedia.org
  • http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stack_Overflow
  • http://www.experts-exchange.com
  • http://codingforums.com

Rotten Tomatoes aggregates film reviews from critics and average viewers

Video profile: http://player.vimeo.com/video/106354048"
Who were the founders? Senh Duong, Patrick Lee, Stephen Wang
When was it started? August 12, 1998
Does it have any interesting origin story? Senh Duong, creative director at Design Reactor, developed the website as a side project, starting with aggregating reviews of all Jackie Chan movies. From its launch, the site was immediately successful, going viral linked with hit movies such as Star Wars: Episode 1 and The Blair Witch Project. Patrick Lee and Stephen Wang tried to convince Duong to come back to Design Reactor, bringing Rotten Tomatoes with him, but eventually decided to instead join him at Rotten Tomatoes as its own entity, with their company, Design Reactor, as a sister company.
What services does Rotten Tomatoes provide? Aggregate movie and TV show reviews by users and critics; provides an aggregate rating.
If this updates a previous service or business model, what does it replace? Professional Movie and TV Show reviews (in newspapers and other publications).
Who uses the services? The user can either expressly go to the Rotten Tomatoes website to look up reviews and ratings or (more commonly), use Flixster to look up showtimes, etc., where the user will also be shown the movies rotten tomatoes score and reviews (from critics and users). As a user, I've only used it in the context of Flixster, but the ratings definitely carry serious weight, and if I see a movie with a low rating (below 60% will show a green rotten tomato), I will often check the reviews, and often not see the movie.
Who are the people who contribute the services? Users with Rotten Tomatoes or Flixster accounts (users can log into Rotten Tomatoes with with Facebook accounts as well). Users can also register as Critics, although they must be cleared as critics at well-standing publications, or something similar. Users' contributions are marked and sorted as either by regular users or by critics.
How does Rotten Tomatoes incentivize them to contribute, or what is their motivation? People are likely to contribute to have their opinions heard, especially if they felt very strongly (in one direction or the other) about a film or TV show. If a user's reviews get many likes, they can become critics and their reviews will carry more weight. There are also message boards on which users can discuss movies, TV shows, etc., so there is a social interaction incentive to communicate and contribute as well.
Is this a service that was previously provided by experts? Yes.
Are the contributors experts/professionals? Yes.
How does Rotten Tomatoes ensure the quality of the services it provides? Rotten Tomatoes staff read critics' reviews and decide whether they are positive or negative. When a film or TV show has received enough reviews, the staff will also write a brief summary on the consensus for the movie that takes in all the reviews. A movie is certified fresh if it has more than 75% positive reviews and at least 40 reviews from Tomatometer critics (5 of which must be top critics). This ensures that they are providing an accurate and well-rounded review of the movie/show.
If Rotten Tomatoes uses a reputation system, how does it work? As above, top critics are cleared by the staff, and their reviews must also have a certain number of likes from other users.
Compare the number of users to contributors: More users than contributors
If its service is provided by many contributors, how are their contributions aggregated? As above, the Rotten Tomatoes staff rates each review as positive or negative, and the final score is the percentage of positive reviews. On Flixster, the reviews are also sorted between users and critics.
Describe the workflow for how the service is advertised, how the contributors contribute, and what the users get in the end: A user goes onto the website or Flixster app, picks the movie she wants to review, and writes her review. The Rotten Tomatoes staff will determine if the review is positive or negative, which will affect the movies score. The review will also be listed when other users look at the movie's rating, either under critics or users, depending on who wrote the review.
What is the scale of Rotten Tomatoes in terms of users? 3,950,000 visitors / day; Alexa Rank: 686
What is the scale of Rotten Tomatoes in terms of dollars? $ 21,329,640 / year
If Rotten Tomatoes were to scale up to 10-100 times its current size, how well do you think would its business model would work? No, because revenue is generated from advertising. Advertising hits viewers as well as contributors, but scaling up contributors does not necessarily increase total views (users + contributors), and further, while ad revenue is more closely linked to total views, it is not linearly correlated.
What kind of organization is it? Part of Flixster, which is owned by Warner Brothers, which is a subsidiary of Time Warner
How does Rotten Tomatoes generate revenue? The company's primary source of revenue, like many web companies, is online advertising
References
  • http://www.rottentomatoes.com/
  • http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rotten_Tomatoes
  • http://stephenwang.com/b/rotten-tomatoes-2000-2005/29/
  • http://fortune.com/2010/07/02/rotten-tomatoes-gets-fresh/
  • https://tv.yahoo.com/news/rotten-tomatoes-fresh-ratings-tv-shows-exclusive-070120791.html
  • http://www.crunchbase.com/organization/flixster
  • http://www.worthofweb.com/website-value/rottentomatoes.com
  • http://articles.latimes.com/2012/jul/18/nation/la-na-nn-rotten-tomatoes-shuts-down-batman-comments-after-death-threats-20120718

Foldit is a collabortation between the University of Washington's Center for Game Science and Dept. of Biochemistry, utilizing crowdsourcing in the form of a game in order to solve a real world problem involving protein geometry
Who were the founders? David Baker and Seth Cooper
When was it started? 2008
Does it have any interesting origin story? The founders were working with another automated solution to predict the natural structures of various proteins. This solution used protein structure prediction algorithms, which take lots of time and processing power to run. This program was later expanded to utilize the processing power of people's PCs around the world to run some of the algorithms. Users began to notice that they could see potential solutions to the structures, but since they couldn't interact with the algorithms they couldn't add their own insights into the program. Thus, FoldIt was born. The founders and their team turned the program into an interactive game that merges distributed computing and algorithmic predictions with the ability for people to tinker with the protein structures themselves.
What services does Foldit provide? It provides people with the opportunity to play an entertaining game while helping scientists solve challenging problems in biochemistry, such as how to target and eradicate diseases in the body.
If this updates a previous service or business model, what does it replace? It replaces a purely algorithmic approach that was used to predict the native structures of various proteins, called Rosetta. This was then extended to utilize the processing power of user's personal computers, by developing a distributed computing program - Rosetta@home. However, users became frustrated that they could not interact with the program itself, eventually leading to an interactive version known as Foldit.
Who uses the services? An individual can sign up to donate a portion of his or her own computing power to assist with the project. In addition, they may participate actively in the game, which lets them play with the different configurations of proteins until they or the program think that they have found a potential solution. This solution is then analyzed by the program to predict how viable the structure is. If it is deemed a realistic possibility, the solution is sent to the experts at the University of Washington for further analysis. Since there are so many possible configurations for each protein, the possibilities are seemingly endless. The contributions from users help accelerate the prediction process.
Who are the people who contribute the services? Anyone, probably mostly online gamers
How does Foldit incentivize them to contribute, or what is their motivation? They have created a game like interface for the program, which in turn provides users with intrinsic motivation to configure better guesses.
Is this a service that was previously provided by experts? Yes.
Are the contributors experts/professionals? No.
How does Foldit ensure the quality of the services it provides? The best guesses from users are first analyzed by the algorithms that the FoldIt team has been working on since the program's inception. The ones that stand out in that pool are presented to the experts themselves, who continuously monitor the quality of the results that the algorithms churn out.
If Foldit uses a reputation system, how does it work? Players are rated based on frequency of success in guessing viable protein shapes. Highest scoring configurations are then sent to experts for further analysis.
Compare the number of users to contributors: Roughly equal numbers
If its service is provided by many contributors, how are their contributions aggregated? All solutions are collected by a central system and rated by viability - the highest scoring entries are then sent to experts for further analysis.
Describe the workflow for how the service is advertised, how the contributors contribute, and what the users get in the end: The service is advertised as is; the website encourages contributors to solve puzzles for science, and explains to them what the goal of the project is and why it matters. The users then play the game, and they get intrinsic gratification when the do well. When they do well, the project's scientists accrue data that will help them solve the puzzles involved in predicting the natural shapes of proteins.
What is the scale of Foldit in terms of users? 240,000 users as of 2012
What is the scale of Foldit in terms of dollars? N/A
If Foldit were to scale up to 10-100 times its current size, how well do you think would its business model would work? It would still work relatively well because a lot of the analysis of how well players do is done algorithmically. However, if there were that many more people playing and contributing viable solutions, the scientists would probably have to expand their human team to keep up.
What kind of organization is it? Research Project
How does Foldit generate revenue? It does not generate revenue, as it is a university sponsored research project.
Anything else? The project is regularly featured in documentaries about how crowd-souring and human computation are changing the future of science.
References
  • http://fold.it/portal/
  • http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Foldit
  • http://www.gamesforchange.org/play/foldit/

Coursera is a free online education platform that partners with universities to offer online classes to users.

Video profile: http://player.vimeo.com/video/106425877"
Who were the founders? Andrew Ng and Daphne Koller
When was it started? April 2012
Does it have any interesting origin story? Coursera was started by two Stanford University computer science professors who wanted to make quality higher education more accessible to the public. Andrew Ng taught a free machine learning course online and found over a 104,000 users from all over the world enrolled for the course. After only a month into teaching the machine learning course, Ng and colleague Daphne Koller left their tenured faculty jobs to start Coursera full time in April 2012 after raising $16 million from a round of venture funding.
What services does Coursera provide? Coursera provides massive open online courses (MOOCs), typically at the university level. These courses are designed and taught by professors at universities that Coursera has partnered with. The format of these courses are short videos, quizzes, and problem sets. In some courses, the pace is set by the user while other courses are regulated by the professor. There is also Q&A section for each course. Verification certificates are offered for some courses for pay. There are also specializations offered; these are essentially a series of courses on a related topic. Specialization certificates are awarded if verification certificates are earned in each of the courses.
If this updates a previous service or business model, what does it replace? Coursera is an improvement in the online education space and is unique in multiple regards compared to previous competitors. It was one of the first (although multiple similar companies, including edX and the Minerva Project, started at the same time) to offer quizzes and problem sets alongside educational videos. Khan Academy, which started in 2006, offers mostly educational videos, without the extra testing. Udacity, which began in January 2012, offers mainly courses in computer science. Coursera has a range of selections, including STEM as well as humanities courses.
Who uses the services? Users of Coursera consist primarily of people who want to learn for their own interests and/or learn new skills that could make them more attractive to employers. Furthermore, Coursera's users wish to learn for free, or learn at only a small cost. Users sign up for an account and then sign up for courses based on their interest areas. Users can then proceed through the videos, quizzes, problem sets, and peer-reviewed assessments of problem sets either at their own pace or, for some courses, at the pace set by the instructor. Courses that are self-paced can be started at any time, but courses that are not can only be joined when sessions are scheduled. All the courses can be taken for free, and once the course is completed, a certification of completion is awarded. Some courses offer “verified certificates” upon completion, but this requires payment from the user. The “verified certificates” are certifications by Coursera and the university providing the course that the user has successfully completed the course; it requires verification of user identity to ensure the user and not someone else is doing the work. Successfully obtaining verified certificates in all of the courses in a specialization series allows the user to get a “specialization certificate.” Specialization series are a group of courses that allow the user to gain skills in a specific area, such as data science or modern music.
Who are the people who contribute the services? The people who contribute services are primarily professors at universities. Coursera has partnered with 100 global universities and 7 non-university partners so far.
How does Coursera incentivize them to contribute, or what is their motivation? The contributors of Coursera (aka the professors) are primarily motivated to participate by their own interest to contribute to the education platform. Many of the universities have their own education initiatives, like Penn's Open Learning program.
Is this a service that was previously provided by experts? Yes.
Are the contributors experts/professionals? Yes.
How does Coursera ensure the quality of the services it provides? The company partners with universities to provide courses so there is some inherent guarantee of quality of the content because of the high level at which the professors who teach the courses are employed. The full process is as follows. University staff work together to ensure the quality of the course description page before it is submitted to Coursera. Coursera then verifies the course description page and uploads it to their website. The instructor must provide a detailed description of the content and resources to be used at least two months in advance through a Course Development Agreement (CDA). The instructor, university staff, and Coursera all sign the CDA, holding them responsible for the class. A minimum amount of content needs to be uploaded a month before the class. Instructor and university staff are responsible for continued content monitoring during the course, and Coursera continues monitoring student discussions and technical issues. If Coursera notices any course issues on the student discussions, it relays it to the instructor. Coursera also develops a system of feedback for the students to offer comments on the course to instructors.
If its service is typically regulated by the government, what are the intents of the regulations and does the company meet those standards? Education at the university level is regulated by the government to some extent. Both public and private universities have to comply with certain government regulations, although private universities typically have much more freedom. The intent of government regulation is to provide a higher quality of education and to improve access to education. With regards to education quality, it's difficult to say whether Coursera meets the government's standards because its goal and approach differs from those at traditional universities. However, being that most courses are taught by professors at well-respected universities, Coursera's courses are of high quality. With regard to accessibility, Coursera does meet government standards.
Compare the number of users to contributors: More users than contributors
If its service is provided by many contributors, how are their contributions aggregated? Each course is individually prepared by staff at a university (or one of the non-university partners), and the courses are aggregated through the Coursera website.
Describe the workflow for how the service is advertised, how the contributors contribute, and what the users get in the end: The service is advertised as a free online educational platform that offers courses in a variety of subjects. The target audience is people who want to learn anything new; many are workers who want to freshen their skills as well as students who want to earn credit or learn something new for no credit. Contributors design courses and teach them through videos, as described in the question about how quality is regulated. The users are able to sign up for courses based on course descriptions for free or for a price if they want a verification certificate from Coursera and the university. After completion, a certificate or statement of completion is given for most courses. A more detailed explanation of verification certificates is in the question about how users use the service.
What is the scale of Coursera in terms of users? Coursera had 7 million registered users as of April 2014, and it had 22,232,448 enrollments as of January 2014.
What is the scale of Coursera in terms of dollars? Coursera had generated $1 million in revenue as of October 2013 (the most recent estimate we found).
If Coursera were to scale up to 10-100 times its current size, how well do you think would its business model would work? We think that if Coursera were to scale up in size, it would still be able to successfully provide its services because it is primarily an internet-based service. However, we also believe that Coursera's current business model is not very profitable and that it will need to modify its business model if it wants to make more profit.
What kind of organization is it? Privately held company
How does Coursera generate revenue? Coursera generates revenue by:

Charging for its Verified Certificates.

Receiving revenue from an Amazon.com affiliates program when users of the website purchase books suggested by professors.
Anything else? Despite having generated relatively little revenue so far, Coursera continues to generate a large amount of venture funding. Their most recent round in November 2013 raised $20 million and the total venture capital so far totals $85 million. Their current business model seems to focus more on the mission statement of providing high-level education to the general public, but it does not seem ideal for generating a lot of revenue. They did not have any substantial revenue before adding the option for paying for certificates in January 2013.

There has also been some talk about providing MOOC users with the a job-finding service and charging commission. Coursera hasn't added a corporate section yet but may do so in the future.

References
  • https://www.coursera.org/
  • http://www.fastcompany.com/3000042/how-coursera-free-online-education-service-will-school-us-all
  • https://www.insidehighered.com/news/2013/04/08/coursera-begins-make-money
  • http://digital.hechingerreport.org/content/mooc-platform-coursera-falls-afoul-of-us-economic-sanctions_1238/
  • http://www.nytimes.com/2014/04/14/education/out-in-front-and-optimistic-about-online-education.html
  • http://www.ipsnews.net/2014/01/u-s-sanctions-closing-doors-education/
  • https://www.provost.umd.edu/announcements/Quality_Assurance_in_Coursera_Courses.pdf

Kickstarter is a crowdfunding website to support creative projects

Video profile: http://player.vimeo.com/video/106446465"
Who were the founders? Perry Chen, Yancey Strickler, Charles Adler
When was it started? 28 April 2009
Does it have any interesting origin story? The founder Perry Chen got the idea after he failed to play a show during the 2002 Jazz Festival because of the lack of funding. He found a great venue and reached out to their management, but in the end the show never happened—it was just too much money. He was bothered by the fact that the potential audience had no say in this decision. Then he started thinking - What if people could go to a site and pledge to buy tickets for a show? And if enough money was pledged they would be charged and the show would happen. If not, it wouldn't. That's where he started looking for partners to start Kickstarter
What services does Kickstarter provide? It provides a platform for people to post their projects and get funding from the crowd. Every project creator sets their project's funding goal and deadline. If people like the project, they can pledge money to make it happen. If the project succeeds in reaching its funding goal, all backers' credit cards are charged when time expires. If the project falls short, no one is charged. Project creators will reward the backers by sharing a piece of their projects to them.
If this updates a previous service or business model, what does it replace? According to a news article in 2009 when Kickstarter was just started, Kickstarter expanded the crowdfunding model by Sellaband to not just bands but more general creative categories. There has been websites providing similar service at the time like FirstGiving, PledgeBank and Mob Incentive. Kickstarter updated the previous model to specifically promote creative projects, and does not take any ownership like some of the past models do - it only provides the platform for people to post and contribute, and started charging 5% of the money raised for its own profit and development.
Who uses the services? In order to make it creative project specific, Kickstarter has limited the categories of crowdfunding to Art, Comics, Crafts, Dance, Design, Fashion, Film & Video, Food, Games, Journalism, Music, Photography, Publishing, Technology, and Theater. For example, if a independent film producer wants to make a theatrical piece but does not have enough funding, he can start a project on Kickstarter to raise money, and if successful, invite those who donate the most to his movie premiere or send copies to them.

A friend of mine who's building his start-up Vigo - a headset that will detect your drowsiness and keep you awake - put a photo of his prototype on kickstarter to raise money for larger manufacturing, and promise to reward donors who donate more than a specific amount by giving them a free copy of the headset once they are manufactured.
Who are the people who contribute the services? In this case, people contributing services are the backers who contribute money to enable project creators to finish their project. It is not particularly a kind of service, but more funding related patronage.
How does Kickstarter incentivize them to contribute, or what is their motivation? Kickstarter uses a all-or-nothing model, meaning that if a project doesn't meet its funding goal, no money will be charged from the users. This gives users incentive to contribute and mediate bystander effect. If people want to see a project come to life, they're going to spread the word. Moreover, project leaders will reward contributors if the project is successfully funded, usually in a related way (e.g. if an art project is successfully funded, contributors will receive a copy of that art)
Is this a service that was previously provided by experts? Yes.
Are the contributors experts/professionals? No.
How does Kickstarter ensure the quality of the services it provides? Since the patronage service from the contributors only include donating money, in this case the quality of the users - people who post their projects - are more important for the quality of the company. Kickstarter's Terms of Use require creators to fulfill all rewards of their project or refund any backer whose reward they do not or cannot fulfill. (This is what creators see before they launch.) This information can serve as a basis for legal recourse if a creator doesn't fulfill their promises. We hope that backers will consider using this provision only in cases where they feel that a creator has not made a good faith effort to complete the project and fulfill. However, Kickstarter does not guarantee projects or investigate a creator's ability to complete their project. On Kickstarter, backers (you!) ultimately decide the validity and worthiness of a project by whether they decide to fund it.
Compare the number of users to contributors: More contributors than users
If its service is provided by many contributors, how are their contributions aggregated? Money pledged by donors is collected using Amazon Payments. No money will be charged before the project reaches its goal, and if it does, Kickstarter will charge the credit cards provided by backers, aggregate all the money, take 5% fee (Amazon will take 3-5% as well) and give the rest to the creator. The platform is open to backers from anywhere in the world and to creators from the US, UK, Canada, Australia and New Zealand.
Describe the workflow for how the service is advertised, how the contributors contribute, and what the users get in the end: When the users want to raise money for their projects, they can post on Kickstarter with the amount of money they want, the cause of their project, detail budget plan, press articles, what they will make as final product, and how much reward people are getting based on their contribution. They can then share the link to social media, their friends and market about their idea to attract more contributor to donate to their product through Kickstarter. Eventually, if the goal is reached, they will get enough money for their product.
What is the scale of Kickstarter in terms of users? 175,240 Project created and 6,961,320 Total backers
What is the scale of Kickstarter in terms of dollars? $1,305,226,696 total dollars pledged to Kickstarter projects
If Kickstarter were to scale up to 10-100 times its current size, how well do you think would its business model would work? I think the model will still work, because Kickstarter does not develop anything themselves or take ownership of any of the projects - they merely provide a platform for creators to post their projects and contributors to donate, so the amount of work for the website itself is minimum - just to maintain the scalability of the site to support more posts, more accounts and more transactions. The incentive scheme wouldn't be affected too much either, because most creators on Kickstarter share the post with their family and friends and get the word out somewhere else through their own channel (interviews, social media, etc). It might only affect the competitiveness of getting featured on Kickstarter, because according to the research done by a Wharton professor, featuring does significantly increase the possibility of success.

The quality model might be affected more, Not for those contributors who come because they heard of their friends' projects or read about it on media or press - because they know the legibility of project creators before they go to those kickstarter pages - but for contributors who just go on Kickstarter and browse for new projects to donate, scaling up to 10 or 100 times means there might be more scams out there on the site (just like Criaglist), and it's much harder to verify with their own judgement since Kickstarter doesn't provide any reputation system or guarantee of completion.
What kind of organization is it? Privately held company
How does Kickstarter generate revenue? Kickstarter originally didn't charge any transaction fee according to an article from 2009, but now charge 5% of all the money raised for a project before giving the money to the project creators.
Anything else? One thing I was trying to figure out at the beginning of this research is whether the creators or the backers on kickstarter are users. Traditionally, on a crowdsourcing website, contributors are those who post and users are using the service, while on kickstarter, the real users are those creators, because they go to the website demanding funding for their projects. Backers became the contributors and contribute their money. Therefore, most content on the site are created by the users. Here the definitions of user and contributor are a bit blurry, because everyone comes to the platform both with some demand and things they can supply, which I think is the core of crowdsourcing platforms - to create a win-win situation for both users and contributors (however they are defined)

References
  • http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kickstarter
  • http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Comparison_of_crowd_funding_services
  • https://www.kickstarter.com/press
  • https://www.kickstarter.com/hello?ref=footer
  • http://www.forbes.com/sites/investopedia/2012/11/07/is-kickstarter-a-viable-platform-for-business-startups/
  • http://www.nytimes.com/2011/08/07/magazine/the-trivialities-and-transcendence-of-kickstarter.html?_r=2&pagewanted=all&
  • http://techcrunch.com/2009/04/29/kickstarter-launches-another-social-fundraising-platform/
  • http://allthingsd.com/20110317/kickstarter-fesses-up-the-crowd-sourced-funding-startup-has-funding-too/
  • http://www.forbes.com/special-report/2013/disruptors/perry-chen_yancey-strickler_charles-adler.html

Yelp sources local reviewers and amateur critics to review local services, thus giving small businesses a way to advertise and be compared by other consumers.
Who were the founders? Jeremy Stoppelman, Russel Simmons, Geoff Donaker
When was it started? Oct. 2004
Does it have any interesting origin story? Stoppelman and Simmons were working on a startup after leaving Paypal when Stoppelman caught the flu. Not having a good method of finding local doctors to consult, he came up with the idea that there should be a service that let consumers rate the services they used locally, so that others would be able to find and use the same services.
What services does Yelp provide? For consumers: solves the pain points of locating and rating services. Makes it easy to find what other customers thought of a specific business.

For small businesses: can pay for advertising to be shown at the top of a search results list, can pay for Yelp to host a Yelp elite party at the business in order to garner more valuable reviews that attract more customers. Improves visibility.
If this updates a previous service or business model, what does it replace?
Who uses the services? I primarily use Yelp to find local restaurants to visit. Going to the page of the restaurant shows other users' reviews and the average rating for the restaurant, allowing me to easily scroll through and pick the one that other people think has the best food. Without Yelp, I would have no way of judging the difference between local restaurants without visiting them myself.
Who are the people who contribute the services? The Yelp elite are people who have been identified as having a certain amount of clout in the community, or who use Yelp on a daily basis and have many followers. These elite users are invited to parties by the company where they then contribute reviews to the business's page, expanding the amount of data and ratings that the business has.

Normal users also contribute ratings and reviews, but there are many users who don't necessarily review every place they've been to.
How does Yelp incentivize them to contribute, or what is their motivation? For Yelp elite, the benefits are free parties (including food and drink) at the business they're invited to review, as well as a host of followers and the ability to be an amateur critic.

For normal contributors, there's always the chance that one will be picked to become Yelp elite. The motivation for users to contribute reviews is mostly because they want to voice their honest opinions about a particular business if they had a great experience or a subpar one.
Is this a service that was previously provided by experts? Yes.
Are the contributors experts/professionals? No.
How does Yelp ensure the quality of the services it provides? There is very common criticism of Yelp and the quality of the reviews and users. The quality checks are crowdsourced as well, with users being able to flag other users and the businesses that own their own pages able to respond or otherwise change the appearance of their reviews page. However, Yelp has been accused more than once of driving revenue by essentially blacklisting some small businesses that do not pay them for advertising services, lowering them to the bottom of the search list or denying the removal of toxic reviews.
If Yelp uses a reputation system, how does it work? Users can rate other users' reviews to be useful, funny, or cool. Users can also ask to be friends with other users, so that some prolific reviewers can gather large followings and thus gain reputation. Yelp elite are designated by the service as such, and their reviews have more value than others due to their reputations.
Compare the number of users to contributors: More users than contributors
If its service is provided by many contributors, how are their contributions aggregated? Reviews are aggregated on the main page of a local business and anyone who visits the page can read them.
Describe the workflow for how the service is advertised, how the contributors contribute, and what the users get in the end: Yelp doesn't do any advertising to look for reviewers, it merely provides a platform where local businesses have pages and reviewers are composed of anyone who has used the service and wishes to post a review. The reviewers type up good or bad reviews, their experiences, what they ate/saw/did, and a star rating of the business, and the users who then visit the webpage can read that review along with others before deciding whether to use the business's service.
What is the scale of Yelp in terms of users? 112 million unique/month
What is the scale of Yelp in terms of dollars? Revenue $233 million as of 2013, but Yelp has never been profitable.
If Yelp were to scale up to 10-100 times its current size, how well do you think would its business model would work? For Yelp to be 10 or 100 times its size, it would have to be in complete control of the entire market that is local business advertising worldwide. Its business model is based off of advertising and search ranking, so it will scale just as Google did. The incentive scheme for local businesses will only increase with the number of users, and the reviews will keep pouring in just as an effect of human nature.
What kind of organization is it? Publicly traded company
How does Yelp generate revenue? The local businesses can pay to advertise their pages, which makes them rise to the top of the search rankings and get more visibility to customers.

A few years ago, Yelp came out with Yelp deals, which displays discounts on each business that Yelp users can claim, thus driving more traffic to the business and getting a cut of the extra revenue generated.

I was told by one of the engineering managers that they're looking to work on a food ordering system and to integrate it with the business pages, much like Seamless/Grubhub/etc.

References
  • http://techcrunch.com/tag/yelp/
  • http://www.nytimes.com/2014/05/23/dining/reviews-on-yelp-help-track-illness.html
  • https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YpDR3iii8HM
  • http://www.pcworld.com/article/249770/beyond_yelp_which_user_review_services_matter_.html

Quora is a Q&A aggregator that incentivizes well-written answers through the earning of digital credits and a lack of anonymity.

Video profile: http://player.vimeo.com/video/106084279"
Who were the founders? Adam D'Angelo, Charlie Cheever
When was it started? June 2009
Does it have any interesting origin story? Not particularly. The founders were both early employees of Facebook who sought to disrupt the Q&A space, which many would agree was somewhat of a mess excluding certain niche communities such as Stack Overflow.
What services does Quora provide? The company allows users to ask and answer questions. Users earn credits from the community by posting interesting questions or well-written and helpful answers. Those credits then allow users to ask experts questions.
If this updates a previous service or business model, what does it replace? Quora is an update to the online Q&A business model. The monetization model is not new as it will likely be heavily ad-based. However, Quora updates the way in which high quality questions and answers are incentivized.
Who uses the services? You first sign up via email, Google, Facebook, or Twitter. You then select a variety of topics you are interesting in. The homepage is a list of questions that Quora believes you may be interested in. I have primarily used it as a tool to find information via pre-existing questions and answers on very specific topics where I desire insider information from experts. Quora has been very good at suggesting questions I may be interested in.
Who are the people who contribute the services? Anyone, although Quora is notable because it also has well-known contributers such as Michael Dell.
How does Quora incentivize them to contribute, or what is their motivation? Quora allows access to better answers to your questions from experts if you spend credits. Credits are only acquired by first providing high quality answers yourself.
Is this a service that was previously provided by experts? Yes.
Are the contributors experts/professionals? Yes.
How does Quora ensure the quality of the services it provides? Quora ensures quality content through the incentive scheme described previously.
If Quora uses a reputation system, how does it work? Users can up-vote questions and answers. Users can also pay credits to experts to receive a presumably high quality answer to a question.
Compare the number of users to contributors: More users than contributors
If its service is provided by many contributors, how are their contributions aggregated? Questions are grouped into topics.
Describe the workflow for how the service is advertised, how the contributors contribute, and what the users get in the end: The service does not appear to advertise via ads. In my experience, much of it's advertising has been via digital word-of-mouth and email sharing. All users are both question- and answer-contributers. Users are incentivized to provide high quality answers in order to receive high quality answers of their own.
What is the scale of Quora in terms of users? Estimated between 3 and 5 registered users. However, Quora notoriously does not share its growth numbers.
What is the scale of Quora in terms of dollars? $0 revenue. $900 million valuation.
If Quora were to scale up to 10-100 times its current size, how well do you think would its business model would work? I think the incentive scheme would scale very well, especially since it has already managed to establish a large community of high quality users with many credits. Since experts and users with an established track record are given higher priority, the system does not succumb to the problems of a pure democracy (e.g. Yahoo Answers).
What kind of organization is it? Privately held company
How does Quora generate revenue? The company generates zero revenue and is still in the funding stages. However, the Founder D'Angelo has stated that the site will likely introduce ads in 2015.
References
  • www.quora.com
  • http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quora
  • http://online.wsj.com/news/articles/SB10001424052702303505504577404510443769988?mg=reno64-wsj
  • http://techcrunch.com/2014/04/09/quora-forever/
  • http://dealbook.nytimes.com/2010/03/30/v-c-s-answer-yes-to-quora/

CrowdMed helps diagnose medical cases by having medical professionals, students, and 'average joes' share their knowledge and expertise.

Video profile: http://player.vimeo.com/video/106359616"
Who were the founders? Jessica Greenwalt, Jared Heyman, Leonardo Setyanto
When was it started? October, 2012
Does it have any interesting origin story? Yes, according to TechCrunch, The company was founded by Jared Heyman, who had previously built the Internet survey company Infosurv. After his sister spent three years with a rare, undiagnosed illness, he realized that the same kind of predictive survey technology could be used to help those who are sick figure out what they are suffering from.
What services does CrowdMed provide? The company crowdsources medical data, while at the same time provides value via its patented predictive technology, to help its users identify illnesses and aid medical professionals.
If this updates a previous service or business model, what does it replace? Users pay for a Med Detective premium, while the company takes a 10% cut.
Who uses the services? A user with an unknown med diagnosis posts there health history/symptoms online allowing all users to solve cases, if they want specialized med detectives they pay a premium.
Who are the people who contribute the services? Healthcare providers, students, and any person who wants to participate solving cases.
How does CrowdMed incentivize them to contribute, or what is their motivation? According to FAQ:

Point rewards and cash compensation offered by patients are awarded to those Medical Detectives who contributed and/or assigned points to the best diagnostic or solution suggestion as determined by the patient or their physician. Patients may also direct up to 50% of their reward points and cash to named Medical Detectives who they found to be most helpful. Note that CrowdMed collects 20% of cash compensation offers as commission.
Is this a service that was previously provided by experts? No.
Are the contributors experts/professionals? No.
How does CrowdMed ensure the quality of the services it provides? When a Medical Detective joins they have 20,000 points to allocate in their suggestions in patient cases, and adjust their points with confidence in that answer. Less popular cases have higher point rewards to help attract more Medical Detectives. Win cases and you get higher quality points, to earn more money. On the case side a refundable deposit needs to be given so that the person is 'real'.
If CrowdMed uses a reputation system, how does it work? The DetectiveRating algorithm factors: winning diagnostic and solution suggestions, point earnings, and peer ratings. DetectiveRating increase by suggesting the best diagnoses and solutions for cases, assigning points to others' suggestions, asking smart questions, and providing well researched insights in case discussions. Earning positive peer and patient ratings, will increase DetectiveRating and reputation points.
Compare the number of users to contributors: More contributors than users
If its service is provided by many contributors, how are their contributions aggregated? Answers aggregated and prioritized based on detective rating, while users can increase reps for certain posts.
Describe the workflow for how the service is advertised, how the contributors contribute, and what the users get in the end: The service is advertised as another venue to recieve professional medical advice from the wisdom of crowds that should be used as a complement to physician practice. Contributors sign up to solve live cases, offer suggestions, and aim to be a part of the solution. If marked as helpful and part of the solution, they are rewarded a share of of the reward, with higher shares going to higher repped members. Users in the end receive another perspective to their med problem that they can use to consult a physician with.
What is the scale of CrowdMed in terms of users? Approximately > 100 users
What is the scale of CrowdMed in terms of dollars? 10-20% of rewards (of about $100-$200).
If CrowdMed were to scale up to 10-100 times its current size, how well do you think would its business model would work? The incentive scheme would scale but as more people get the answer correct the more the reward money could be split up. The incentive scheme for patients versus users would have to stay at a 1:30 ratio to keep balance in profitable cases with helpful advice.
What kind of organization is it? Privately held company
How does CrowdMed generate revenue? CrowdMed collects 20% of cash compensation when a patient offers reward or pays for Med Detectives (higher rated users to solve the case).

References
  • http://techcrunch.com/2013/04/16/crowdmed/
  • https://www.crowdmed.com/newsroom
  • http://www.startribune.com/business/258540431.html
  • http://www.nbc12.com/story/26498455/crowdmed-uses-crowdsourcing-to-diagnose-medical-problems

Uber provides the personal chauffeur driven car experience to anyone and a marginally greater price.
Who were the founders? Garrett Camp, Travis Kalanick
When was it started? March 2009
Does it have any interesting origin story? Uber began in 2009 in San Francisco as UberCab with the mobile applications being launched for both Android and iPhone in 2010. By late 2011 the company had raised almost $49.5 million dollars in venture capital funding from Angel Investors in the Silicon Valley area as well as institutional investors such as Goldman Sachs, Menlo Ventures etc.
What services does Uber provide? The company provides Ridesharing services. It works like a call a cab taxi service but provides chauffeur driven luxury vehicles at a marginally higher cost. The app provides billing and guidance and payment is made electronically via a credit / debit card.
Who uses the services? If you're looking for a taxi or a ride, you open the UBER app and specify your pickup location. You also specify the kind of vehicle you would like. Once an appropriate vehicle has been found the driver is contacted and messaged your details and he goes to pick you up from your specified location. After the driver drops you off you end the trip and exit the vehicle. Your credit card is automatically charged the fare for the trip.
Who are the people who contribute the services? Anyone who owns a vehicle as specified by Uber's requirements and falls in one of the categories of cars they offer to customers can sign up to be a driver for Uber. They must meet certain standards and specifications but once they're approved they use the Uber app on their device to provide service to customers.
How does Uber incentivize them to contribute, or what is their motivation? Uber drivers are paid for every ride they undertake. The payment depends on the duration and distance covered. By pooling in available drivers Uber gives them higher custom than they'd be able to source on their own in the luxury travel sector.
Is this a service that was previously provided by experts? Yes.
Are the contributors experts/professionals? Yes.
How does Uber ensure the quality of the services it provides? Uber ensures that the drivers contributing to the Uber network pass stringent quality and standard checks before they're officially commissioned to become a part of the Uber network.
If Uber uses a reputation system, how does it work? After each ride, the customer has an option to rate the ride overall out of 5 stars as well as rate the ride under specific categories such as driver courtesy, cleanliness of the vehicle, driver professionalism etc.
If its service is typically regulated by the government, what are the intents of the regulations and does the company meet those standards? Technically, Uber doesn't fall under a Taxi service and is thus exempt to many regulatory restrictions placed on Taxis. That said it is a car hire service and does require the drivers to have licenses as well as the cars to be registered. These regulations are enforced in order to ensure passenger safety and curb traffic violations.
Compare the number of users to contributors: More users than contributors
If its service is provided by many contributors, how are their contributions aggregated? As customers rate a particular driver, the driver gets a rating out of 5 stars which is just the average of all the customer ratings the driver has received.
Describe the workflow for how the service is advertised, how the contributors contribute, and what the users get in the end: Uber's advertising is mainly through word of mouth and online advertisement. A popular campaign gave users their first ride free of charge upto a $40 limit. The second campaign gave every user $20 of Uber credit in case someone they referred to Uber signed up and took a ride. They even gave the referred person a $20 Uber credit voucher.

The contributors are the Drivers who sign up to drive for Uber, pass the quality control and requirements checks and then begin servicing Uber customers. Uber sends the drivers a notification when a customer requests a vehicle which matches theirs and they then go provide the customer with transport services.

For the customer, it provides easy simple door to door service. Their credit cards are directly charged eliminating the whole paying after a ride business. Uber can be called anytime via the app and come pick you up for free. Additionally the cars are all luxury vehicles and the drivers are professionals.
What is the scale of Uber in terms of users? 12,000,000 completed rides in 13 - 14
What is the scale of Uber in terms of dollars? $1,109,303,828
If Uber were to scale up to 10-100 times its current size, how well do you think would its business model would work? Logically Uber's business model is highly scalable. As Uber works on a commission basis, scaling would dramatically increase revenue. That said, because it's still a niche service only requested by select customers, it can be that scaling a 100 times would disrupt the supply - demand equilibrium that Uber has managed to achieve in the market today.
What kind of organization is it? Privately held company
How does Uber generate revenue? For every ride, Uber charges commission for providing the ridesharing / matching services. Uber takes a 20% cut from the final fare paid by the passenger.

References
  • http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uber_(company)
  • http://www.theatlantic.com/technology/archive/2010/11/hailing-a-cab-with-your-phone/66630/
  • http://www.cnet.com/news/car-service-uber-raises-32-million-launches-in-paris/
  • http://www.forbes.com/sites/aswathdamodaran/2014/06/10/a-disruptive-cab-ride-to-riches-the-uber-payoff/
  • http://www.inc.com/magazine/201307/christine-lagorio/companies-that-are-like-uber.html

Comuni-Chiamo is a crowdsource problem management tool for municipalities
Who were the founders? Gilberto Cavallina
When was it started? 2012
Does it have any interesting origin story? The company was started because historically, municipalities in Italy have had a hard time dealing with problems such as fixing roads and picking up garbage. More than merely signalling the problems to the local government (of which they're often already aware), it gives the local representatives incentive to fix the problems and recorded accountability if they don't, as italian politicians often sweep issues like this under the rug
What services does Comuni-Chiamo provide? It is essentially a waze for signalling problems in common areas within municipalities, such as roads, traffic lights, destruction in public parks, etc. The service aggregates all these citizen's signals and makes the list available to both the community and local government officials.
Who uses the services? I've never used it because it is still not available in my municipality in Italy. But this service is intended for any citizen with a smart phone! It works particularly well in Italy because there are a lot of evident problems that go unfixed for years...
Who are the people who contribute the services? Normal citizens who are tired of having small and easily fixable problems in their municipality
How does Comuni-Chiamo incentivize them to contribute, or what is their motivation? the fact that the problem will eventually be resolved. But even more than that, the fact that they can hold government officials accountable for not taking care of the problems. With this app people in the government can no longer claim they didn't know about the problem. Also, normally signalling problems to local gov't is a huge hassle because you have to go to a police station and file a lot of paperwork, which obviously not many are willing to do!
Is this a service that was previously provided by experts? No.
Are the contributors experts/professionals? No.
How does Comuni-Chiamo ensure the quality of the services it provides? they ask for evidence of the problem one sees and they don't allow duplicate entires about the same problem
If its service is typically regulated by the government, what are the intents of the regulations and does the company meet those standards? it doesn't break any regulations because it is simply signalling. They are just taking the hassle and paper work out of filing a formal problem report with the local gov't
Compare the number of users to contributors: More contributors than users
If its service is provided by many contributors, how are their contributions aggregated? they don't allow duplicate reports for the same problem, but people can comment on hot and more pertinent topics to ensure they will be looked at more promptly
Describe the workflow for how the service is advertised, how the contributors contribute, and what the users get in the end: it's not really advertised in the mainstream, but only in the municipalities it currently operates in (~30). People contribute by signalling the problem and providing evidence of it on the platform. The user in the end will *hopefully* get this problem resolved by the municipality. The more people comment or make a specific problem 'hot', the more likely gov't officials will divert their attention to fixing it.
What is the scale of Comuni-Chiamo in terms of users? ~300,000-500,000
What is the scale of Comuni-Chiamo in terms of dollars? N/A
If Comuni-Chiamo were to scale up to 10-100 times its current size, how well do you think would its business model would work? it would work perfectly well because the incentives are extremely tangible even on a larger scale. People will have problems with the state of their municipality on a micro-level. The only problem I see is that if this is done in a place like NYC, then there's simply going to be too many reports for the gov't to possibly fix, but then again, the more people agree with one specific problem, the more attention it will get from the gov't
What kind of organization is it? Privately held company
How does Comuni-Chiamo generate revenue? Through geo-targeted advertising
Anything else? Let's go Italy!!
