Duolingo is a free language education and text translation platform.
Who were the founders? Luis von Ahn and Severin Hacker
When was it started? November 2011
Does it have any interesting origin story? Duolingo was originally started as an academic project at Carnegie Mellon between Luis von Ahn and his PhD student Severin Hacker. Luis von Ahn was born and raised in Guatemala and saw firsthand how expensive it was to learn English, so after selling his second company reCAPTCHA to Google in 2009 Von Ahn decided to shift his focus towards language education. Von Ahn and Hacker had weekly half-hour meetings between 2009 and 2011 discussing ways to improve language education, resulting in the creation of Duolingo.
What services does Duolingo provide? Duolingo provides a free learning platform for individuals to learn a new language. At the end of lessons, the app allows users to practice by translating real articles. By combining many translations from high-level users, Duolingo can create an accurate translation of an article. As a result, Duolingo also acts as translation service for companies such as BuzzFeed and CNN. In addition, Duolingo has a language certification service. To add new languages incubators are created so that bilingual individuals can come together and help build curriculums.
If this updates a previous service or business model, what does it replace? Duolingo updates both the language learning business model and the text-translation business model. Duolingo is able to provide a free language learning service for people, as opposed to other fee-based learning platforms. It also makes the learning process into a game by creating short exercises and awarding badges and points. At the same time, it is able to generate revenue by using the more traditional approach of charging companies for article translations.
Who uses the services? Duolingo's services can be accessed both through their website and their downloadable app. It is free and available to anyone who creates a profile. The sign up process takes about 30 seconds and only requires an email. After signing up, a user just clicks on a language he/she wants to learn and can begin doing exercises. The current courses available for english speakers are primarily romance languages such as Spanish, French, Italian, etc. For non-english speakers the languages available are very limited. As users get better with a language, they can click on immersion and translate real articles for practice.
Who are the people who contribute the services? People who are learning a language on Duolingo also contribute text-translations for articles that are sold to companies such as BuzzFeed and CNN. The curriculums themselves are also crowdsourced by bilingual communities that are moderated by Duolingo.
How does Duolingo incentivize them to contribute, or what is their motivation? Users are motivated to contribute and translate articles because it will help them learn a new language.
Is this a service that was previously provided by experts? Yes.
Are the contributors experts/professionals? No.
How does Duolingo ensure the quality of the services it provides? Duolingo assures the quality of the translations by aggregating many translations of top performing users. In addition, peers can upvote translations and proofread translations. To ensure curriculum quality, adding new languages is a thorough process. There are three phases for the language incubator: private, beta, public. To contribute, users must apply and show they are fluent in both languages. There are also moderators that compile and edit work. The company continually does A/B testing on curriculums to improve the effectiveness of exercises.
If Duolingo uses a reputation system, how does it work? As exercises are completed in the curriculum, users are given points and badges which quantifies how well they know the language. In addition, user translations are checked by peers and are assigned upvotes or downvotes based on the quality. As you translate more articles you move up translation tiers.
Compare the number of users to contributors: More users than contributors
If its service is provided by many contributors, how are their contributions aggregated? Duolingo takes the translations of many users and combines them to create an accurate translation. Translations are also checked by peers to ensure they are accurate. When creating curriculums the company uses many contributors to create the content and then uses moderators to compile and edit work. A patented algorithm is used to ensure quality of the curriculums.
Describe the workflow for how the service is advertised, how the contributors contribute, and what the users get in the end: A language curriculum is created by a group of bilingual users (most major languages already have a curriculum). An individual signs up for Duolingo and chooses one of these languages. The individual completes game-like exercises and gains experience points. As the individual gains proficiency he/she will choose articles to translate to practice skills. These articles have been posted to the website by organizations who will pay Duolingo for the translation service. Many individuals translate the same article. These translations are aggregated and given to the organization. In the end, the individual learns a language, the company gets an article translated, and Duolingo makes a small profit.
What is the scale of Duolingo in terms of users? 38 Million Users
What is the scale of Duolingo in terms of dollars? Duolingo does not provide revenue numbers; however, profit is estimated to be in the hundreds of thousands
If Duolingo were to scale up to 10-100 times its current size, how well do you think would its business model would work? The business model is relatively scalable for wide spoken languages such as Spanish and French. As more companies join, there should be enough users to fill demand. As more users join, the learning process would not be affected so incentives will remain unchanged and quality will remain unaffected. However, scalability will most probably be limited for languages that are not in high demand due to the fact that not enough bilingual individuals will exist to generate the curriculum and not enough users will be able to translate the articles.
What kind of organization is it? Privately held company
How does Duolingo generate revenue? Organizations can upload documents onto Duolingo to be translated for a fee. The company has contracts with BuzzFeed and CNN to translate articles for their international websites. In addition, Duolingo also has a language testing service similar to the TOEFL iBT that it charges $20 for.
References
  • https://www.duolingo.com/
  • http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Duolingo
  • http://techcrunch.com/2011/04/12/duolingo/
  • http://www.crunchbase.com/organization/duolingo
  • http://www.quora.com/Duolingo-language-tool/What-is-the-history-of-Duolingo
  • http://www.forbes.com/sites/parmyolson/2014/01/22/crowdsourcing-capitalists-how-duolingos-founders-offered-free-education-to-millions/
  • http://www.slate.com/articles/technology/technology/2014/01/duolingo_the_free_language_learning_app_that_s_addictive_and_fun.html
  • http://www.pcmag.com/article2/0,2817,2425382,00.asp
  • http://www.fastcolabs.com/3029531/how-duolingo-uses-a-b-testing-to-understand-the-way-you-learn
  • http://www.corporatelearningnetwork.com/technology-digital-learning/articles/bonjour-apprentissage-how-gamification-made-duolin/

Silk Road is an anonymous marketplace, operated as a Tor service, that allowed users to buy and sell narcotics and other goods.

Video profile: http://player.vimeo.com/video/106529777"
Who were the founders? Dread Pirate Roberts is the pseudonym of the founder and operator of Silk Road. Ross William Ulbricht is currently accused of being DPR.
When was it started? February 2011
Does it have any interesting origin story? Silk Road was founded by Dread Pirate Roberts, or DPR, as what he or she calls a practical libertarian system. It was founded and designed to run on libertarian principles of no centralized power (like the government) and free markets.

Designed so that the state couldn't touch it for a very long time, Silk Road was built by DPR, not just for monetary reasons, but primarily to make a difference in the world markets. He or she believes that in such a free market environment, the existence of drug cartels and violence is minimized to almost zero, and the competitive nature of Silk Road also enforces quality products from vendors.
What services does Silk Road provide? The company is an online marketplace. It works like any other marketplace like Amazon or eBay, in that it allows users to act like vendors or customers.

Vendors essentially stock the shelves at Silk Road, and put up goods for sale (typically shipped to any part of the world, from any part of the world) and customers place orders, and review the service and quality of goods provided by the various vendors.

Silk Road differs from Amazon and eBay, though, for 2 major reasons:

1. Silk Road is completely anonymous. It used a Tor system which encrypts the location and meta-data of anyone accessing and hosting the website, making it really difficult for authorities to track down users. It also conducts all transactions in BitCoin, an online currency, which is unregulated in the global markets.

2. Apart from your regular goods like books, apparel, and merchandise (which comprise only a small fraction of transactions on Silk Road), the main bulk of transactions are narcotics from marijuana to LSD and heroin.
If this updates a previous service or business model, what does it replace? It's Amazon-if Amazon sold mind-altering chemicals - Adrien Chen, Editor, gawker.com.

Silk Road builds off typical e-commerce sites like Amazon and eBay (it certainly doesn't replace them, though). As stated before it enhances privacy by running on the Tor system and allowing trades only by BitCoin, and is used primarily for buying and selling narcotic substances.
Who uses the services? There is actually a blogspot post on using Silk Road titled Silk Road for Dummies (Linked in the reference section).

A typical user would download the Tor Browser, so that their IP and other meta-data is private, and would find the newest link to the Silk Road website.

They could then browse through the various goods on offer and purchase them via BitCoin. They have an escrow system by which you first need to make a deposit to Silk Road. Silk Road then transfers the money internally to the sellers account. The seller can withdraw this money in BTC at any time and even hedge the trade to the USD price of BTC at the time of the sale. DPR would pay any difference accounting from the volatility of BTC.

Finally, you are shipped your goods by regular mail and can go back to Silk Road and rate the seller for the experience, quality, reliability, etc.
Who are the people who contribute the services? Anyone who wants to sell a gram of marijuana or a book to people who want to sell large quantities of heroin contribute their listings to Silk Road. The primary vendors are people who have a large number of listings of various quantities, some even offering sample packs for free.

Contributors tend to use the same pseudonym to gain a reputation and good reviews. This helps them sell more and contributors who try to scam the system are blocked out by low reviews. This exemplifies the free market environment that DPR founded the website for.
How does Silk Road incentivize them to contribute, or what is their motivation? Anyone looking to sell illicit goods is incentivized to sell on Silk Road because of the following reasons:

1. It is a free market and anyone can make their mark.

2. Formation of cartels is impossible and violence due to drug turf wars and drug deals are almost eliminated.

3. The privacy system was very well designed and the website ran without the authorities being able to bust it for almost 2 and a half years.

4. Silk Road provides a platform to sell goods from anywhere on the world to anywhere else (though most users were based in the US and the UK).
Is this a service that was previously provided by experts? Yes.
Are the contributors experts/professionals? Yes.
How does Silk Road ensure the quality of the services it provides? The company tries to provide a free marketplace by really empowering the consumers through reviews. Consumers rate vendors and vendors with low ratings naturally die out. Further, Silk Road has certain rules that it enforces in terms of what can and cannot be sold on their website. Silk Road does not allow its vendors to sell child pornography, weapons, stolen credit cards, and contracts for murder. The company considers these against their morals because they consider it to cause harm to other innocents.
If Silk Road uses a reputation system, how does it work? The reputation system works just like the review system of Amazon does. Customers purchase goods from vendors and rate them out of 5 stars.

Most vendors who scam and provide low quality service are naturally left out of the environment. Most vendors, however, have high rating which signals a very competitive environment, with high customer satisfaction.
If its service is typically regulated by the government, what are the intents of the regulations and does the company meet those standards? Government regulations prohibit or control sale of many of the goods and substances that are sold on Silk Road. The intent of these regulations is to prohibit unhealthy usage of and addiction to these drugs.

Silk Road was made to provide the world with an alternate and unregulated marketplace based off the concepts of libertarianism.
Compare the number of users to contributors: More users than contributors
If its service is provided by many contributors, how are their contributions aggregated? Various products by many contributors are listed and sorted in terms of department. Search features allow users to browse through all the listings, listings by department, or listings by a particular contributor.
Describe the workflow for how the service is advertised, how the contributors contribute, and what the users get in the end: The service is very low key and not highly advertised. It's more of a word of mouth system that gets people on the site, as well as some blogs with the correct and updated url of the site.

Contributors choose to list products. Users can choose to buy these products, and the users get their product shipped to them. They can then review the vendor and his or her services.
What is the scale of Silk Road in terms of users? About 146,946 buyers and 3,877 seller accounts.
What is the scale of Silk Road in terms of dollars? $1.2 Million worth of transactions every month.
If Silk Road were to scale up to 10-100 times its current size, how well do you think would its business model would work? An online market or e-commerce platform on a 10 to 100 times scale exists and scaling could definitely be possible in terms of the aggregation model, reviews, quality, incentive scheme, and business model.

What would be difficult to predict is whether there would be a compromise in terms of privacy because it might be difficult for the Tor system to scale up so much.
What kind of organization is it? Privately held company
How does Silk Road generate revenue? Silk Road charges a premium of every transaction that occurs on its website. Trade volumes on the website at its peak were about 1.2 million USD a month and revenue was close to $92,000 per month.

References
  • http://arstechnica.com/tech-policy/2014/08/dark-net-drug-markets-kept-alive-by-great-customer-service/

  • http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Silk_Road_(marketplace)

Lyft is an app that lets its users request friendly, safe, affordable transportation.

Video profile: http://player.vimeo.com/video/106350183"
Who were the founders? Logan Green, John Zimmer
When was it started? 2007
Does it have any interesting origin story? Lyft was initially launched as a service for Zimride, a ridesharing company that focussed more on long trips between cities. In 2013, Zimride's name was changed to Lyft
What services does Lyft provide? Lyft facilitates peer-to-peer ridesharing by allowing passengers to request a ride from certified community drivers.
If this updates a previous service or business model, what does it replace? Lyft updates the Taxi/public transportation system by allowing anyone to supply transportation with appropriate certification. This sort of crowd sourcing is much different from centralized taxi companies or public transportation services.
Who uses the services? I need a ride to my doctor's appointment from campus and don't have a car, so I go on the Lyft app and request a ride.
Who are the people who contribute the services? Those who drive the cars.
How does Lyft incentivize them to contribute, or what is their motivation? Community drivers make donations from the passengers they transport.
Is this a service that was previously provided by experts? Yes.
Are the contributors experts/professionals? No.
How does Lyft ensure the quality of the services it provides? Any driver averaging less that 4.5 stars is dropped from the service.
If Lyft uses a reputation system, how does it work? Lyft uses a stars system for its drivers to maintain quality service.
If its service is typically regulated by the government, what are the intents of the regulations and does the company meet those standards? Any transportation service has regulations due to its nature. Safety is a big concern, so drivers receive a background check, are required to be 21 and have a year of driving experience, as well as necessary vehicle inspections and about a one-hour training session. Individual states' legislation has proven problematic for Lyft. For example, in New York, their drivers are required to be certified Taxi drivers, which dramatically changes the normal business model.
Compare the number of users to contributors: More users than contributors
If its service is provided by many contributors, how are their contributions aggregated? Lyft aggregates the contributions of its drivers in that the drivers all transmit their locations and passengers are assigned to the nearest driver.
Describe the workflow for how the service is advertised, how the contributors contribute, and what the users get in the end: Lyft advertises directly to passengers. Drivers contribute by offering their car as a form of transportation for strangers. In the end, users get a service that is more comfortable and conveient than other forms of transportation.
What is the scale of Lyft in terms of users? 10,000-100,000s
What is the scale of Lyft in terms of dollars? $100m
If Lyft were to scale up to 10-100 times its current size, how well do you think would its business model would work? Lyft would remain very similar if it scaled up 100+ times because that would just mean it established itself in cities all over the US and world. They would have to deal with much more litigation but the basics of the business would remain essentially the same.
What kind of organization is it? Privately held company
How does Lyft generate revenue? Lyft takes a 20% cut of each transaction.
Anything else? They are sweet!
References
  • http://www.crunchbase.com/organization/lyft
  • https://www.lyft.com/
  • http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyft

IndieGoGo
Who were the founders? Danae Ringelmann, Slava Rubin, and Eric Schell
When was it started? 2008
Does it have any interesting origin story? Ringelmann co-produced a play while working on Wall Street, but had trouble funding it even though it was popular. She wanted to find alternative revenue streams for funding, and went to business school to develop a business that would democratize funding.
What services does Indiegogo provide? It allows users to source funding for all sorts of projects (Personal, Charitable, Start-Ups, etc) from individual people who contribute amounts that are far smaller than amounts a venture capital source would invest in something. It also allows users to contribute to other user's projects, either in return for some perk (a product or some other alternative to an equity stake), or in return for nothing.
Who uses the services? Someone might design a prototype for a new type of wearable technology and need more funding to get through the initial production phase. They might create a campaign on Indiegogo soliciting donations and in return for certain levels of donations, offer copies of the product when it is completed (like pre-orders).
Who are the people who contribute the services? Anyone at all can contribute money.
How does Indiegogo incentivize them to contribute, or what is their motivation? They participate because they believe in the cause or project, think something is a cool idea, or want to pre-order the product (at a discount).
Is this a service that was previously provided by experts? Yes.
Are the contributors experts/professionals? No.
How does Indiegogo ensure the quality of the services it provides? It does not guarantee fraud protection (it used to but removed the guarantee). Instead, it does claim to have algorithms that monitor its services and processes to protect against fraud that include reviewing contributors and companies and then performing a final review before funds are disbursed.
If its service is typically regulated by the government, what are the intents of the regulations and does the company meet those standards? The intents are to regulate equity and debt investments in companies. Through the JOBS act of 2012, regulation applies to crowdsourcing equity and debt funding as well. However, the regulations do not apply to Indiegogo or its major competitor Kickstarter because they do not offer returns on investment in the form of equity or debt agreements. They only allow contributions, which may be in return for concrete products or perks.
Compare the number of users to contributors: More contributors than users
If its service is provided by many contributors, how are their contributions aggregated? Funds are pooled collectively with progress visible to the public.
Describe the workflow for how the service is advertised, how the contributors contribute, and what the users get in the end: Users make an posting including a video/pitch and what perks they are offering. Contributors can browse the various projects posted and decide what to donate to. The users at the end receive funds (minus fees) as long as the campaign is successful in reaching its funding target, unless they chose flexible funding.
What is the scale of Indiegogo in terms of users? 10's of thousands to hundreds of thousands of campaigns are run
What is the scale of Indiegogo in terms of dollars? Hundreds of millions of dollars are raised by all users combined
If Indiegogo were to scale up to 10-100 times its current size, how well do you think would its business model would work? I think that its model would work pretty well, there is nothing about its concept that would struggle to scale since it is entirely electronic.
What kind of organization is it? Privately held company
How does Indiegogo generate revenue? The company charges users who post projects for funding a percentage of the funds raised.

  • http://pando.com/2014/04/03/after-pando-shows-clear-evidence-of-fraud-on-indiegogo-company-responds-by-deleting-anti-fraud-guarantee/
  • https://www.crowdfunder.com/blog/knowledge-center/crowdfunding-law/

A hospitality website for people to rent our lodging.
Who were the founders? Brian Chesky, Joe Gebbia, Nathan Blecharczyk
When was it started? August 2008
Does it have any interesting origin story? In 2007, two of the founders were not able to pay their rent for their SF loft at the time. So they made their living room into a bed and breakfast, accommodating three guests on air mattresses and providing homemade breakfast. Hence the name Air b and b. To raise money, they designed boxes of cereal with a presidential candidate on them and sold them for $40/box, before landing seed money from Sequoia Capital and YVentures.
What services does Airbnb provide? The company provides a place where people can rent lodging. People can rent out their entire house or a room in their house. Every property is associated with a host whose profile includes recommendations by other users, reviews by previous guests, as well as a response rating and private messaging system.
If this updates a previous service or business model, what does it replace? Airbnb acts as an alternative rental/hospitality service option.
Who uses the services? I used the service on my spring break trip to Puerto Rico last year. I was traveling with 5 other college students and we rented an apartment in San Juan for 4 days. We carefully picked the lodging based on our budget and the reviews of the hosts, which were really helpful in our selection process. We were able to meet the host the morning we got there and she was very nice and gave us a place to store our luggage until the apartment was freed up from the previous guests and cleaned up by the maid. Overall, it was a really great experience and it was really nice to have an entire apartment to ourselves and be able to cook and relax on a big couch, things that would have not been possible if we stayed in a hotel.
Who are the people who contribute the services? Pretty much any willing individual can list their space on Airbnb and be a host. Listing options range from the entire house to dorm to igloo to tent.
How does Airbnb incentivize them to contribute, or what is their motivation? Airbnb primarily provides the platform that connects hosts to travelers. The incentive for the host is to make money on what would otherwise be unutilized space. The company also expanded it's services, including insuring hosts in case of theft or destruction of property, thus providing safeguards for hosts, and professional photographers to better advertise spaces.
Is this a service that was previously provided by experts? Yes.
Are the contributors experts/professionals? No.
How does Airbnb ensure the quality of the services it provides? Airbnb has three ways of trying to ensure quality for both the guests and the hosts. First, hosts and guests must verify their identities, including photo ID and Facebook or LinkedIn profile match. Secondly, Airbnb has a profile and review system in place. Thus, poor quality will eventually reflect in the reviews, ensuring quality for other users and incentivizing better quality. Lastly, hosts and guests are able to message each other to personally screen one another.
If Airbnb uses a reputation system, how does it work? Every user has an online Airbnb profile. Host profiles will include recommendations by other users, reviews from previous guests, and ratings.
If its service is typically regulated by the government, what are the intents of the regulations and does the company meet those standards? The government does have hospitality laws in place to protect guest' safety and avoid negligence. Hotels, for example, must protect the confidentiality of their guests' identifying information. Airbnb has been under criticism for it's intrusive verification process, of which it is unclear as to who has access to that information or how it is used by the company. Due to its failure to meet hotel occupancy taxes, Airbnb is also illegal in NYC and San Francisco under many circumstances.
Compare the number of users to contributors: More users than contributors
If its service is provided by many contributors, how are their contributions aggregated? It is aggregated on a single web platform.
Describe the workflow for how the service is advertised, how the contributors contribute, and what the users get in the end: Once a host has signed up, they may list there space on Airbnb's platform. Airbnb also provides a service that will send professional photographers to a host space to take better pictures and better showcase the space for potential guests. Guest can then select a location, contact the host and vice versa. In the end, the user get to use the space listed for a certain period of time.
What is the scale of Airbnb in terms of users? More than 2.1 million registered users
What is the scale of Airbnb in terms of dollars? $2,5 billion valuation; $794.8 Million in funding
If Airbnb were to scale up to 10-100 times its current size, how well do you think would its business model would work? The company would scale well. Airbnb has grown from 120,000 listings at the start of 2012 to over 300,000 listings now. Guest numbers are growing exponentially as well. The company understands that they have to grow continuously to support the community..
What kind of organization is it? Privately held company
How does Airbnb generate revenue? Airbnb make money directly from its users and contributors. At the moment, Airbnb charges hosts a 3% host service fee and guests a fee ranging from 6-12%.
References
  • www.google.com
  • www.wikipedia.com

  • http://www.nydailynews.com/life-style/real-estate/airbnb-investigation-users-article-1.1929849
  • https://www.eduson.tv/blog/airbnb

Indiegogo in a crowdfunding platform which enables people around the world to make donations towards realizing ideas that require lots of funding.
Who were the founders? Danae Ringelmann, Slava Rubin, Eric Schell
When was it started? 2008
Does it have any interesting origin story? One of the co-founders, Danae Ringelmann worked in New York at JPMorgan. She was part of a networking group that connected with the media and entertainment industries. There, she realized that it was extremely difficult for independent filmmakers or producers of theatrical events to raise the funds needed for their ventures, and wanted to create a platform that better met their needs.
What services does Indiegogo provide? It provides a platform of a social marketplace where people with ideas or small companies share their ideas with the world and others who believe these ideas are worth funding, can make donations.
If this updates a previous service or business model, what does it replace? For small companies, filmmakers, and other independent, small groups, Indiegogo replaces the need to network directly with the large funding and investment groups. Instead, it allows them to take their ideas straight to the masses who donate very many small amounts of money.
Who uses the services? Anyone with an idea can use this site. This includes filmmakers, companies, inventors, photographers, etc. An example of a large and well known company that used Indiegogo to fund one of their technologies was Canonical. Canonical used Indiegogo to raise over $12 million for their Ubuntu Edge smart phone.

In order to do this, they provided a description of the product needing funding, both through a video and written explanation. They then set a funding goal and deadline.
Who are the people who contribute the services? Anyone who has access to the internet, can read the descriptions of products needing funding, and has the money to donate can contribute money on Indiegogo.
How does Indiegogo incentivize them to contribute, or what is their motivation? Mostly, contributors are motivated by their passion for the idea/product and this leads them to donate money. However, sometimes, the company or person behind the campaign can offer perks for donating certain amounts of money, which is also an incentive to contribute.
Is this a service that was previously provided by experts? Yes.
Are the contributors experts/professionals? No.
How does Indiegogo ensure the quality of the services it provides? While donations and contributions are non-refundable, the company does say that Our detection algorithms analyze data, spot suspicious activity, and identify any users attempting to take advantage of the platform. In addition, our team of Trust & Safety experts identifies, reviews, and removes users and campaigns that may try to abuse the system. Thus, if many people have the same problem with the same campaign, it can probably be resolved.
If Indiegogo uses a reputation system, how does it work? Slightly, it shows how much money campaigns have raised so far, and which campaigns are trending currently.
Compare the number of users to contributors: More contributors than users
If its service is provided by many contributors, how are their contributions aggregated? Since the contributions are of a monetary nature, the donations are just combined under the campaign.
Describe the workflow for how the service is advertised, how the contributors contribute, and what the users get in the end: First the people behind the idea come together and create a campaign. The better the campaign and the more people behind it, the better. Next, they engage their community and share the campaign with as many people as possible. As the campaign becomes more successful, it improves its location on the Explore campaigns part of the website. This is where contributors are looking at campaigns that they potentially want to donate to. Once the campaign period is closed for donations, the users get the money that was donated.
What is the scale of Indiegogo in terms of users? It provides one services, which is a online funding platform.
What is the scale of Indiegogo in terms of dollars? It depends on the campaign. There have been campaigns that have only raised a few hundred dollars and also campaigns that have raised over 12 million dollars.
If Indiegogo were to scale up to 10-100 times its current size, how well do you think would its business model would work? I think their business model would work pretty well. It is already quite a huge social funding marketplace. Perhaps the only thing that would suffer or be compromised is that smaller campaigns would have more difficulty gaining traction. However, there are different tabs and ways with which to search for different types of campaigns, so perhaps further developing those technologies would help to solve that problem.
What kind of organization is it? Privately held company
How does Indiegogo generate revenue? Indiegogo charges between a 4-9% fee on the funds raised by groups that use their platform. If a group achieves their goal, they are charged a 4% fee and if not, a 9% fee. This helps keep expectations within reason.
Anything else? Some of the questions were a little confusing for me to understand, but hopefully I answered them correctly. Overall, while Indiegogo doesn't provide a ton of services or have a lot of requirements or qualifications for contributors, I think its a really cool company and that I can still make a decent company profile presentation for it.

Wikipedia is a free-access, free-content Internet encyclopedia.

Video profile: http://player.vimeo.com/video/106356466"
Who were the founders? Jimmy Wales and Larry Sanger
When was it started? January 15, 2001
Does it have any interesting origin story? Wikipedia developed from Nupedia, a free-online encyclopedia. The founders then had the idea to have users edit their own encyclopedia.
What services does Wikipedia provide? Free encyclopedia then can be edited by users.
If this updates a previous service or business model, what does it replace? Nupedia
Who uses the services? I have never updated an article, but I regularly use wikipedia to get a brief summary on any topic. I have always found the information to be of high quality(except in obscure topics).
Who are the people who contribute the services? Anyone can edit Wikipedia articles.
How does Wikipedia incentivize them to contribute, or what is their motivation? Wikipedia does not incentivize contributors. Contributors have identified the belief that knowledge should be free, values, and fun as motivation.
Is this a service that was previously provided by experts? Yes.
Are the contributors experts/professionals? No.
How does Wikipedia ensure the quality of the services it provides? New edits to Wikipedia are screened, and rollbacks to earlier versions are easy to perform. Biased users are also usually balanced by views from the other side, leading to neutral content remaining. Random users without accounts cannot make edits.
Compare the number of users to contributors: More users than contributors
If its service is provided by many contributors, how are their contributions aggregated? Wikipedia contributors also deal with the aggregation of the information provided by other contributors.
Describe the workflow for how the service is advertised, how the contributors contribute, and what the users get in the end: Contributors can edit most pages and the end user sees the edited page.
What is the scale of Wikipedia in terms of users? 73,251 active users/ 22,437,253 accounts
What is the scale of Wikipedia in terms of dollars? n/a
If Wikipedia were to scale up to 10-100 times its current size, how well do you think would its business model would work? Because most of the quality/aggregation is done by the users, I think that the business model would work well if it was larger. This is assuming that the system isn't flooded with mostly malicious users.
What kind of organization is it? Non-profit organization
How does Wikipedia generate revenue? Wikipedia is supported by the non-profit Wikimedia.

Wikipedia is a free-access, free content Internet encyclopedia.

Video profile: http://player.vimeo.com/video/106356466"
Who were the founders? Jimmy Wales and Larry Sanger
When was it started? January 15, 2001
Does it have any interesting origin story? Not really.
What services does Wikipedia provide? Wikipedia provides a free access online encyclopedia.
If this updates a previous service or business model, what does it replace? Other encyclopedias such as Encyclopedia Britannica.
Who uses the services? Anyone who is looking for information on a particular subject will use this service. I have used Wikipedia countless times, whether to learn about a new subject or for help with a concept I don't understand.
Who are the people who contribute the services? Anyone can edit Wikipedia articles, as long as they have Internet and the capability to go to the Wikipedia site. However, only registered users can make new articles. Some articles are also semi-protected, meaning that only certain editors can make changes to the articles.
How does Wikipedia incentivize them to contribute, or what is their motivation? The company does not do much to incentivize contributors. Contributors are purely volunteers who wish to improve the quality of information available on the site.
Is this a service that was previously provided by experts? Yes.
Are the contributors experts/professionals? No.
How does Wikipedia ensure the quality of the services it provides? Wikipedia has a set of administrators and bureaucrats. Administrators are given the role of deleting incorrect material when they come across it, deleting unsuitable articles, and blocking disruptive users. Bureaucrats are given the role of appointing new administrators.
Compare the number of users to contributors: More users than contributors
If its service is provided by many contributors, how are their contributions aggregated? Contributors can make edits to articles or post new articles. Other contributors can then continuously edit these articles until the community feels that all important information about the subject has been written.
Describe the workflow for how the service is advertised, how the contributors contribute, and what the users get in the end: The service is not really advertised, the contributors can freely make edits whenever they deem it necessary, and users get more accurate information in the end.
What is the scale of Wikipedia in terms of users? 500 million
What is the scale of Wikipedia in terms of dollars? Net Worth - 12.8 billion
If Wikipedia were to scale up to 10-100 times its current size, how well do you think would its business model would work? The incentive scheme is practically non-existent, yet people continue to contribute to the site. I would imagine that scaling the business would not change the percentage of people who contribute. The quality of contributions would most likely be worse initially, but would then plateau at where it is at now.
What kind of organization is it? Non-profit organization
How does Wikipedia generate revenue? Since Wikipedia is non-profit, it generates revenue solely through donations. Anybody who wishes to donate can, and single donations have reached as high as 2 million dollars.
References
  • http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia
  • http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_Wikipedia

Couchsurfing is a platform that facilitates the meeting of open-minded travelers.

Video profile: http://player.vimeo.com/video/106654731"
Who were the founders? Casey Fenton, Daniel Hoffer, Sebastian Le Tuan and Leonardo Bassani da Silveira.
When was it started? 2004
Does it have any interesting origin story? In 1999, co-founder Casey Fenton found a cheap flight from Boston to Iceland. Hoping to find similarly cheap accommodation, he randomly emailed 1500 students from the University of Iceland, asking if he could crash with them. He ultimately received 50 responses offering him a place to stay. He realized that people were open to the idea of sharing cross-cultural experiences in exchange for accommodation, and when he returned to the states he started intermittently working on code for a couchsurfing website. The Beta version of the site was launched in 2003, after the other co-founders joined the project, and today the site has over 9 million members in 120,000 cities.
What services does Couchsurfing provide? Couchsurfing connects travelling Couchsurfers with hosts in the cities they will be travelling to. No money is exchanged for accommodation; rather, the expectation is that hosts and surfers will spend time together and learn more about each other's cultures. The website also facilitates short-term meetups between travelers and hosts, and several major cities have regular potlucks, language exchanges and other meet-ups to which all hosts residing in and all surfers passing through the area are invited to.
If this updates a previous service or business model, what does it replace? Couchsurfing provides a crowdsourcing tool that facilitates and streamlines the process of meeting a new friend in a new city who will welcome you into his or her home. Previously, this could be done by intrepid travelers who had the serendipity of meeting someone while travelling who they connected with, but Couchsurfing provides a means of turning strangers into new friends and facilitating cultural exchanges en masse.

It also updates and expands on previous free accommodation projects around the world, like that of the Tumbleweeds at the famed Shakespeare & Co. bookstore in Paris.
Who uses the services? 86% of CS's users are between 18 and 34, but as the network expands, the demographics are diversifying, and committed CS enthusiasts are maturing along with the network. Most people I have Couchsurfed with have been under 35. This group has included a wide range of people including:

-A philosophy Ph.D student at the University of Edinburgh

-A Peruvian hotel receptionist in Rome who spoke 5 languages fluently and who welcomed me into his Mediterranean penthouse over the Christmas holidays

-Several businessman, ranging from the man tasked with expanding Marks & Spencer from the UK into France to the man who coordinated all refrigerators of Ben & Jerry's to a financial services professional who had worked in London, Zurich and now Paris

-A software programmer in Tallinn who described himself as like a cat who likes to meow sausages from strangers

-A completely blind 26-year-old in Ghent. We were his 123rd & 124th CSers he had hosted and he said it was his way of giving back to a world that has been far too kind to him.
Who are the people who contribute the services? I think it's hard to distinguish whether or not someone is a contributor on CS--both surfers and hosts contribute in their own way, since the entire point of the network is to facilitate cross-cultural exchange.

Still, I suppose a more traditional definition of contributor would be whether or not someone hosts. Most people I have met who are surfers have also hosted at some point, though I've noticed that women surfers are more wary than men surfers of later becoming hosts. Some people are also super hosts, and have hosted hundreds of people.
How does Couchsurfing incentivize them to contribute, or what is their motivation? For travelers, I think that the motivation for starting to use the network is that it's a great way to save money. But then once you get into it you realize it's also a great way to make friends and really get to know the local culture beyond what a guidebook can help you learn. Couchsurfing makes finding a new friend (or a group of friends) in each city you travel to easily, and if you read through each potential host's profile carefully and scrutinize their reviews, I find CS provides an excellent system of pairing surfers and hosts with people they will learn from and enjoy being around.

As for hosts, I have found that some get into hosting at times in their lives when they're lonely--when they have just been through a break-up or a divorce, or have just moved to a new city. That's not to say that CS is full of hosts who are mopey. Quite the contrary--it's full of hosts who are being brave and pushing themselves to branch out. Other hosts get into CS because they wish they had the opportunity to travel but they don't have the time to, and CS provides an excellent way of bringing the world to you. Others get into it because they have some extra space and are generous, curious people who are looking to make friends.

Once people get into CS, I think what keeps people coming back is that it restores your faith in humanity. There is a section on each member's profile where they're asked to list their opinion of the CS project, and I have seen countless reviews about how CS has opened their world, taught them that it can be okay to trust a stranger, and made the world seem like a more welcoming and less fearsome place. Many members will say things like CS could change the world.
Is this a service that was previously provided by experts? Yes.
Are the contributors experts/professionals? No.
How does Couchsurfing ensure the quality of the services it provides? Couchsurfing's safety & quality maintenance system is comprised of four parts: references, verification, friends, and vouching.

-References are public reviews left for the surfer or host by friends and previous surfers, hosts, and fellow travelers. When leaving a review, an overall rating of positive, neutral or negative is assigned and then the reviewer can provide an in-depth account of his/her experience hosting, surfing with or travelling with that member.

-Verification, as explained above, occurs when the member pays a $25 fee to help support the community and has his/her location verified.

-Vouches are given by superhosts and CS Ambassadors to members who they are confident are assets to the community

-Friends are the final component. CS is a social network, and members can add friends who they have made both before and during their travels.

In addition to these features, CS offers a comprehensive menu of features that allow a user to report and messages or behavior that violates community standards.

A user's profile also provides a means of verification and quality control, as profiles with pictures that are thoroughly filled in offer overviews of each member's personality, language proficiencies, accommodation offerings, preferences, quirks, and dedication to the CS project and to travel.
If Couchsurfing uses a reputation system, how does it work? The reputation system is the basis of CS's security & quality control:

-References are public reviews left for the surfer or host by friends and previous surfers, hosts, and fellow travelers. When leaving a review, an overall rating of positive, neutral or negative is assigned and then the reviewer can provide an in-depth account of his/her experience hosting, surfing with or travelling with that member.

-Vouches are given by superhosts and CS Ambassadors to members who they are confident are assets to the community

-Friends are the final component. CS is a social network, and members can add friends who they have made both before and during their travels.
Compare the number of users to contributors: Roughly equal numbers
If its service is provided by many contributors, how are their contributions aggregated? CS offers only general data on the impact that the project is having around the world, but it is clear that the impact of the project is spreading fast.

In places like Europe, it is relatively simple to string together a 30-45 day trip that will completely involve CS-ing.
Describe the workflow for how the service is advertised, how the contributors contribute, and what the users get in the end: The service is primarily advertised through word of mouth, and through the publicity it generates as people debate (with more or less open minds and with more or less experience with the project) in nationally syndicated publications whether or not it's safe to stay with strangers.

The contributors (hosts) offer a free place to stay for 1-X nights (usually 2-4 in my experience, but sometimes longer). Depending on the means of the host and what he/she wishes to do, they may also offer their surfers a simple breakfast, but this is not required. Very, very rarely have I merely slept on a couch--by far most hosts offer a spare bed or a futon, or at least have an air mattress for the floor. Hosts generally offer sheets, blankets and towels as well.

Surfers contribute by showing up, being friendly and curious, and making an effort to spend time with their host. Though at first blush many people see surfers as moochers, CS actually provides an amazing means of cultural exchange--members can practice their language skills with each other, and hosts get the chance to see their city from the eyes of their guests, and people get to make new friends from around the world and learn more about other countries and what people from other places think of their country.
What is the scale of Couchsurfing in terms of users? 9000000
What is the scale of Couchsurfing in terms of dollars? $22.6 million
If Couchsurfing were to scale up to 10-100 times its current size, how well do you think would its business model would work? I think this would work terribly. Since August 2012 the CS community has doubled in size, and one sad side effect is that more and more people are getting involved who see CS-ing as just a way of finding a place to stay for free. There is also the annoying problem of men (and maybe some women, though I haven't really heard of any) who misunderstand the network and think it is a way of facilitating hookups and easy sex. Thankfully, these spammy messages are easily filtered out and reportable.

CS is a place for wanderers, for the curious, and for travelers, not tourists. While I'm happy to see more and more wonderful and worthy people getting involved with the community, the expansion of the network's numbers also means that it is incumbent upon members to do more community policing of people who just don't get it.
What kind of organization is it? Privately held company
How does Couchsurfing generate revenue? There are two ways that CS generates revenue. Currently, the primary source is the investment money the company has raised from investors including General Catalyst Partners, Omidyar Network, and Menlo Ventures. $22.6 million has been raised from these streams in the past year.

The other source of CS's revenue is the $25 fee that members pay to become verified members. A card is sent to their home, and a code on the back, once entered into the CS system, confirms their location and verifies that they are a legitimate enough person to have a credit/debit card and that they have provided an accurate address. The verified member option is touted as a source of safety/security, and I find that more men become verified members than women because it's a way of increasing the trust that surfers and hosts will place in them.
Anything else? I love CS and I hope that my presentation will convince more Penn students to join the network

Foursquare is a mobile app that provides personalised search experience for its users according to their tastes which they give to the app.
Who were the founders? Dennis Crowley, Naveen Selvadurai
When was it started? March 11, 2009
Does it have any interesting origin story? Dodgeball was Dennis Crowley's first attempt at social networking for mobile phones and was acquired by Google in 2005.

When Google neglected the project, Crowley founded an improved location-based social game he named Foursquare.

Foursquare is based of the playground game, and is called such because it is supposed to be fun and playful.
What services does Foursquare provide? Local search and recommendations:

Foursquare lets you search for restaurants,shopping areas and other locations in your surrounding area. It is also possible to search other areas by entering the name of a remote location.

Users have the ability to 'Like' tips left by other users.Users can also save tips left by other users onto their own to do list, ensuring that the user is reminded about them when they are nearby, and can follow any other user or brand to increase the prominence of that user's tips when they are navigating Foursquare.
If this updates a previous service or business model, what does it replace? Magazines that provided reviews by only a handful of people
Who uses the services? 1. Power Users -. They spend inordinate amounts of time contributing to the website. They might be moderating categories on Wikipedia, writing 100's of restaurant / bar reviews on Yelp, checking-in and commenting on ever Foursquare venue or even writing entire transcriptions of TV shows on ViiKii.net. Or let's face it - writing lots of answers on Quora

2. Casual Contributors - These people are uninterested in achieving status on your website. They had a very positive or negative experience and they want to tell the world. They are passionate about a topic (like this one for me!) and they feel inclined to spend some time contributing.

3. Lurkers. Most UGC sites try to spend time converting lurkers to contributors. Don't. 90% of all users will never contribute anything to your company. They are there to ingest content.


Who are the people who contribute the services? The users and contributors come from the same groups of people.

However the contributors can also be restaurants and local set ups.

For example: he may advertise a free good for the mayor(a foursquare member) of the region.
How does Foursquare incentivize them to contribute, or what is their motivation? Social Responsibility is the primary motivation behind public reviews and tips.This builds social capital. People with a good experience want to share their positive feedback as it is convenient for others.
Is this a service that was previously provided by experts? Yes.
Are the contributors experts/professionals? No.
How does Foursquare ensure the quality of the services it provides? Foursquare tries to ensure the privacy of its users.Privacy is integral to a company like foursquare.

Foursquare's Services deal with location, so in order to work, the Services need to know your location. Whenever you open and use/interact with our apps on your mobile device or go to one of our Sites, we use the location information from your mobile device or browser (e.g., latitude and longitude) to tailor the Services experience to your current location (i.e., we'll show you a list of nearby locations, friends and tips). This information is NOT shared with others
Compare the number of users to contributors: More users than contributors
If its service is provided by many contributors, how are their contributions aggregated? The reviews are aggregated and maintained with a reference to people tastes and preferences.

It also records attributes such as price range, friends preferences etc.


Describe the workflow for how the service is advertised, how the contributors contribute, and what the users get in the end: Most users access Foursquare with an application loaded on their smartphones, but it's also possible to update the service on your movements through the Foursquare Web site or by sending a text message. After you have signed up for a free account on the company's Web site and installed the application on your phone, you can activate the program any time you visit a location. Foursquare accesses your phone's GPS receiver to pinpoint your position and then lists nearby locations. After you choose which place you are visiting, the application updates your status to let other users know. If you update your status at the same location enough times, you can even earn badges or become the mayor of that location. Users can also use the location information to plan face-to-face meetings
What is the scale of Foursquare in terms of users? 50 million
What is the scale of Foursquare in terms of dollars? 15 million
If Foursquare were to scale up to 10-100 times its current size, how well do you think would its business model would work? The business model would only succeed further because such applications have enormous network externality. i.e. as each additional individual joins

the value of the application to all the existing users.

Especially if users come from new markets.
What kind of organization is it? Privately held company
How does Foursquare generate revenue? Advertisments
